data.value: Your action plan summarizes some of the key steps you should take to optimize your health and reduce your risk for chronic diseases and other conditions. You are not expected to make all these changes at once.

data.name: L1000
data.value: The calculator cannot be used to provide risk estimates for individuals under age 40 years, over age 79 years and/or with known cardiovascular disease.

data.name: L1002
data.value: Your Heart Age (based on your risk for heart disease) is {0}. To see how certain key factors affect your Heart Age, change the values alongside the risk factors. Values with an exclamation point (!) may be in need of improvement.

data.name: L1003
data.value: Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (‘ASCVD’) is the disease that causes heart attacks and most strokes. The graph below shows your risk (or likelihood) of developing or dying from ASCVD in the next 10 years. For this graph, ASCVD is defined as having a first heart attack or stroke or dying from coronary heart disease or stroke. As you can see, based on your risk factors, you have a {0} risk of ASCVD in the next 10 years. Someone your age, sex and race with optimal risk factor levels would be expected to have a {1} or lower risk of ASCVD in the next 10 years. To see how certain key factors affect your risk, change the values alongside the risk factors. Values with an exclamation point (!) may be in need of improvement.

data.name: L1004
data.value: Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (‘ASCVD’) is the disease that causes heart attacks and most strokes. In the graph below, ‘Your Risk’ is the lifetime risk (or likelihood) of developing or dying from ASCVD for a person at age 50 years with your risk factor levels. For this graph, ASCVD is defined as having a first heart attack or stroke or dying from coronary heart disease or stroke. As you can see, at age 50 years a person with your risk factor levels has a {0} risk of developing or dying from ASCVD in the future. Someone at age 50 years with optimal risk factor levels would be expected to have a {1} or lower lifetime risk of ASCVD. To see how certain key factors affect your risk, change the values alongside the risk factors. Values with an exclamation point (!) may be in need of improvement.

data.name: L1015
data.value: Most adults don't get as much exercise as they need to be healthy. Scientists have identified many health benefits of aerobic exercise. Examples of aerobic exercise include brisk walking, jogging, swimming, cycling, skating, dancing, climbing stairs, rowing, and other similar activities.

data.name: L1017
data.value: Reduce your risk of dying prematurely

data.name: L1018
data.value: Reduce your risk for heart attack, stroke, and some types of cancer

data.name: L1019
data.value: Prevent or control high blood pressure

data.name: L1020
data.value: Raise your HDL ("good") blood cholesterol and lower blood triglyceride levels

data.name: L1026
data.value: Strengthen your bones and prevent osteoporosis

data.name: L1028
data.value: Relax and sleep better at night

data.name: L1029
data.value: Expanding your physical activity program to include "lifestyle physical activities" as well as traditional exercise can help you increase your activity and learn new ways to fit in exercise. For example:

data.name: L1030
data.value: Take the stairs instead of the elevator

data.name: L1031
data.value: Park farther away from the store and walk the extra distance

data.name: L1036
data.value: In addition to aerobic exercise, strength or "resistance" training can also be of benefit to you. Strength training helps maintain muscle while losing fat. Because of this, strength training is an important part of a weight management program. It helps prevent your metabolism from slowing down and may even cause it to speed up. Strength training also has other positive benefits, including

data.name: L1039
data.value: Less pain in the back and joints

data.name: L1043
data.value: Improved function, especially in the older years

data.name: L1044
data.value: Generally, healthy adults should perform moderate-intensity aerobic physical activity (such as brisk walking) for a minimum of 150 minutes each week OR vigorous-intensity aerobic physical activity (such as jogging) for a minimum of 75 minutes each week OR an equivalent combination of moderate- and vigorous-intensity aerobic physical activity. Most adults should also do muscle-strengthening activities that involve all major muscle groups on two or three days each week. See My Action Plan for your personalized physical activity recommendations, including whether or not it is important for you to obtain clearance from your doctor before participating in an exercise program.

data.name: L1045
data.value: My Safety and Warning Signs to be Aware of

data.name: L1047
data.value: For safety reasons, a warm-up period is recommended as you begin each exercise session. Likewise, a cool-down period should follow at the end of the exercise session. Perform the exercise you intend to do, but at a slower pace, for at least five minutes at the beginning and end of each exercise session. Walking is an excellent way to warm-up and cool-down for any type of exercise.

data.name: L1048
data.value: Start off slowly and progress gradually

data.name: L1049
data.value: The best way to prevent muscle and other injuries is to not overdo things. Listen to your body. Minor muscle soreness is common at first, but goes away as your fitness improves. Don’t push yourself so hard you don’t enjoy the exercise you do or feel tired for a long time after you have stopped.

data.name: L1051
data.value: Drink one cup of water every 20 to 30 minutes during exercise, especially if it’s hot and humid.

data.name: L1052
data.value: Stop exercising immediately and call your doctor if you experience any of these symptoms

data.name: L1053
data.value: Pain or discomfort in your chest, abdomen, back, neck, jaw or arms

data.name: L1054
data.value: Unusual shortness of breath during exercise

data.name: L1057
data.value: An irregular pulse (if it is usually regular)

data.name: L106
data.value: In the PAST YEAR, how many days of work have you missed due to PERSONAL illness or disability (regardless of time-off benefits)?

data.name: L1066
data.value: Eating healthy isn’t about depriving yourself. Every food can be part of a healthy eating plan. It’s about how much and how often. Variety and balance are important. You should eat foods from all of the basic food groups every day.

data.name: L1067
data.value: Although no foods are completely off limits, you should limit your intake of

data.name: L1068
data.value: Fats, especially "unhealthy" fats – namely, saturated fats (from fatty meats, butter and hard margarine, whole-fat dairy foods, tropical oils) and trans fats (hydrogenated or partially hydrogenated fats in shortening, baked goods, regular peanut butter, and fried foods)

data.name: L1069
data.value: Cholesterol (found only in animal foods, such as meats, egg yolks, and dairy foods)

data.name: L107
data.value: In the PAST YEAR, how many days of work have you missed due to your having to take care of a sick or disabled FAMILY MEMBER?

data.name: L1070
data.value: Foods with added sugar ("unhealthy" carbs) – candies, syrups, jams/jellies, sweetened beverages and regular sodas

data.name: L1071
data.value: Refined grain products and refined grains used as ingredients ("unhealthy" carbs) – instant cooked cereals, some ready-to-eat cereals, white rice, white flour, and bread, crackers, and pasta made from refined flour (even enriched flours and cereals lack fiber)

data.name: L1072
data.value: Sodium (added to commercially-prepared foods or added in cooking or at the table)

data.name: L1073
data.value: Alcohol (no more than two alcoholic drinks a day for men and no more than one drink a day for women). If you are trying to lose weight, it is best not to drink at all

data.name: L1074
data.value: Although you may need to limit your portions, you should choose

data.name: L1075
data.value: Fruits ("healthy" carbs) – fresh, dried, frozen, and canned without added sugar. Eat the whole fruit rather than drinking fruit juices, which are lower in fiber, although fruit juices can be part of a healthy eating plan

data.name: L1076
data.value: Vegetables ("healthy" carbs) – choose colors (dark green, orange, red, and yellow), fresh and raw without added fat. Eat the skins as much as possible. Soy protein products – tofu, textured vegetable protein, soy milk and cheeses – are also recommended in moderation

data.name: L1077
data.value: Whole grains ("healthy" carbs) – excellent sources of vitamins, minerals, and fiber

data.name: L1078
data.value: Fish, especially oily fish such as salmon, trout, tuna, herring, and sardines (rich in healthy omega-3 fats), and other foods containing omega-3 fats ("healthy" fats)

data.name: L1079
data.value: Lean meats (skinless chicken and turkey, Canadian bacon) and meat substitutes (egg whites or substitutes, nuts and natural peanut butter)

data.name: L108
data.value: In the PAST YEAR, how many times have you visited an emergency room due to PERSONAL illness or injury?

data.name: L1080
data.value: Monounsaturated fats ("healthy" fats found in olive oil and canola oil)

data.name: L1082
data.value: Low-fat or fat-free milk and yogurt

data.name: L1083
data.value: Within each food group there are healthier choices to make. Saturated fats and trans fats are "unhealthy" fats and refined grains and foods with added sugar are "unhealthy" carbs. In contrast, monounsaturated fats and omega-3 fats are "healthy" fats and fruits, vegetables, and whole grains are "healthy" carbs. Review the lists below to help you make healthier choices.

data.name: L1147
data.value: Rather than focusing on a single nutrient or food, follow a meal plan that is designed to improve your total eating habits. Consistent with this principle, we recommend eating a variety of fruits, vegetables, and grain products, especially whole grains; choosing fat-free or low-fat dairy products, legumes, poultry, and lean meats; and eating fish, preferably oily fish, at least twice a week.

data.name: L115
data.value: Do you ever ride in a vehicle without wearing a seat belt?

data.name: L1151
data.value: Find out what could happen if you led a healthier lifestyle...

data.name: L1157
data.value: Everyone agrees: Life is stressful. Too much stress is related to a variety of serious health problems, including an increased risk for heart disease. For this reason, stress management is important. Learning about stress and how to manage it will improve both your physical and emotional health, and your overall quality of life.

data.name: L1158
data.value: If you are trying to manage your weight, it is especially important for you to learn stress management skills. Sometimes stress may cause you to overeat or quit following your meal and exercise plans.

data.name: L1159
data.value: Stress is a two-part process: cause and effect.

data.name: L116
data.value: Do you ever drive 10 mph (16 km/h) or more over the speed limit?

data.name: L1160
data.value: The cause is called the "stressor." Stressors can be real or imagined. Most things you worry about in life – your stressors – never happen. The source of stressors may be social, psychological, or physical. Examples of stressors are provided below.

data.name: L117
data.value: Do you ever ride a bicycle without wearing a bicycle helmet?

data.name: L118
data.value: Do you ever drive or ride on a motorcycle without wearing an approved safety helmet?

data.name: L1180
data.value: The effect a stressor has on you is called the "stress response." The stress response has also been called the "fight or flight" response. When you are faced with a stressor, your body experiences a series of physical changes intended to help you fight the stressor or flee from it. These changes are complex and involve the nervous system and the endocrine (hormones) system. Some common physical responses to stress include:

data.name: L1185
data.value: Muscle tension causing goose bumps and making hair stand on end

data.name: L1186
data.value: Increased blood sugar level to use as energy

data.name: L1187
data.value: Dilation of the pupils to enhance vision

data.name: L1188
data.value: Blood flow directed to muscles and liver (hands and feet feel cold)

data.name: L1189
data.value: Increased blood clotting for protection if injured

data.name: L1190
data.value: For early humans, the "fight or flight" response was their means of survival. Today, most stressful situations don't require a fight or flight response to survive. In fact, in today's world, you are more likely to let stressors build up or become excessive before taking action. Unfortunately, if left unchecked, stress can cause problems to your health and well being.

data.name: L1191
data.value: Not all stress is bad. Without some stress, there could be no progress in life - no reason to get up in the morning. Some stress is needed for growth and challenge. One goal of stress management is to shift from always viewing stress as negative and damaging, to viewing it - whenever possible - as something that is positive, inevitable, and necessary.

data.name: L120
data.value: Do you have working smoke detectors in your home?

data.name: L121
data.value: Do you have a working fire extinguisher in your home?

data.name: L1215
data.value: Excitement is a mostly positive feeling. It is how you respond to a challenge. When you are confronted with a situation for which you are well prepared, you get excited as you think about a good experience. You may feel a burst of energy, a rapid heartbeat, or "butterflies" in your stomach. Your feelings of excitement may even alternate with feelings of nervousness.

data.name: L1216
data.value: Stress is the feeling of being overwhelmed. When faced with a challenge, you may have the confidence to handle the situation if only you had more time to prepare yourself. You may believe you will fail or disappoint someone, maybe yourself. You may begin to feel pressured to work harder, do better, and be perfect. You feel tense and irritable as your head hurts and your stomach ties up in knots.

data.name: L1217
data.value: At the earliest signs of excitement or stress, take steps to prevent negative feelings.

data.name: L1218
data.value: Anxiety is the point where you perceive something negative or bad might happen and you do not believe you will be able to do anything about it. You begin to worry about it over and over until you can't get the situation out of your mind.

data.name: L1219
data.value: Depression is at the end of the continuum. People who are depressed constantly perceive life as threatening and dangerous. They begin to lose all hope about controlling these threats, and may become lethargic and feel they will never be able to change anything. They give up trying to cope and they feel worthless.

data.name: L1220
data.value: Professional help is needed when feelings of depression are experienced.

data.name: L1221
data.value: There are many ways to relax. Choose a technique you think you will enjoy. Deep breathing exercises are one of the easiest techniques to learn. You can do deep breathing anytime, anywhere. It can be done sitting, standing, or lying down, as long as you are comfortable. Wear loose clothing or loosen your tie, belt, or buttons. A quiet place is recommended, although not necessary.

data.name: L1222
data.value: 1. Begin by breathing in slowly and deeply through your nose. While breathing in, count to five and silently say the word "in" to yourself. Notice that your abdomen relaxes as your lungs fill with air.

data.name: L1223
data.value: 2. After the count of five, purse your lips and let the air escape slowly as you count to five and say the word "out" to yourself.

data.name: L1224
data.value: Repeat the exercise (up to five minutes, if time permits). With practice, you may be able to count to 10 during each phase of the exercise. You can increase your relaxation if you imagine breathing in ocean air, the scent of flowers or forest air and visualize a restful place.

data.name: L123
data.value: When you lift up a heavy object, do you always bend your knees and keep your back straight?

data.name: L1237
data.value: Take the basic preventive actions outlined below to reduce your risk for motor vehicle accidents and other unintentional injuries.

data.name: L1238
data.value: My Basic Information – Motor Vehicle Accidents

data.name: L1239
data.value: Motor vehicle accidents are a leading cause of death, especially in children and young adults. Motor vehicle accidents are the leading cause of years of potential life lost before age 65.

data.name: L124
data.value: Complete physical exam during the past three years

data.name: L1240
data.value: To reduce the risk for motor vehicle crash-related injuries, there are certain basic preventive actions that we should all take. These preventive actions include:

data.name: L1242
data.value: Never drive while under the influence of alcohol or other drugs

data.name: L1243
data.value: Never ride in a vehicle operated by someone who is under the influence of alcohol or other drugs

data.name: L1244
data.value: Always use seat belts (even when driving or riding in an automobile equipped with air bags)

data.name: L1245
data.value: Urge all other passengers to wear seat belts at all times

data.name: L1246
data.value: If you carry infants or toddlers in your vehicle, install and use federally approved child safety seats in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions and the child’s size; rear facing infant seats should not be placed in the front seat of a car equipped with a passenger-side air bag – the safest seating position in the car is the middle of the rear seat

data.name: L1247
data.value: Passengers should not ride in the cargo beds of pickup trucks

data.name: L1248
data.value: Passengers should not ride in the cargo areas of station wagons or vans except when those areas are fitted with passenger seats and seat belts

data.name: L1249
data.value: If you drive or ride on a motorcycle, always wear an approved safety helmet

data.name: L125
data.value: Stool test for colon cancer during the past 12 months

data.name: L1250
data.value: My Basic Information – Household and Recreational Injuries

data.name: L1251
data.value: Unintentional injuries are a leading cause of death in all age groups. As is the case for motor vehicle crash-related injuries, there are certain basic preventive actions that we should all take to reduce the risk for unintentional injuries. These preventive actions include:

data.name: L1252
data.value: Install and maintain smoke detectors in the home

data.name: L1253
data.value: Safely store matches and lighters, and do not allow anyone to smoke near bedding or upholstery

data.name: L1254
data.value: Set hot water temperatures to 120 – 130 degrees F (49 – 54 degress C)

data.name: L1255
data.value: If you have guns in your home, keep guns unloaded and stored in locked cabinets separate from ammunition

data.name: L1256
data.value: If you ride a bike, always use a bicycle helmet

data.name: L1257
data.value: Safely store medicines and other potentially dangerous household products; keep syrup of ipecac on hand if you have young children in your home and know the poison control center telephone number

data.name: L1258
data.value: Avoid alcohol use during water-related activities such as swimming and boating

data.name: L1259
data.value: If you have young children in your home, supervise them carefully when in the bathtub or swimming, and install isolation fences around your swimming pool if you have one

data.name: L126
data.value: Sigmoidoscopy during the past five years

data.name: L1260
data.value: If you have elderly people in your home, correct home hazards related to falls; if you have elderly relatives, make them aware that falls are the leading cause of nonfatal injuries and unintentional injury deaths in older people

data.name: L1264
data.value: I would like to complete my blood test at a:

data.name: L1267
data.value: As a smoker, you already know quitting is the right thing to do. Friends and family members have probably urged you to quit and social norms have banned you from smoking in public places. Most smokers say they want to quit, but smoking is also one of the hardest habits to break.

data.name: L1268
data.value: If you have been smoking for a number of years, you may have even tried to quit. Maybe you’ve tried to quit several times. Usually people make several attempts to quit smoking before they are able to quit for good. Studies have shown that each time you try, you learn from the experience.

data.name: L1269
data.value: The decision to quit and your long-term success are greatly influenced by the advantages you see to quitting - your "pros." Your reasons to quit must be important to you. While it is good to listen to your doctor, spouse, or children, you have to quit because YOU want to. Internal motivation is key.

data.name: L127
data.value: Pap test during the past three years

data.name: L1270
data.value: The link between cigarette smoking and lung cancer and chronic lung diseases has been proven for years. But smoking causes more than just breathing problems.

data.name: L1271
data.value: Smoking is a major risk factor for heart attacks and strokes.

data.name: L1272
data.value: Even a single cigarette has harmful effects. Smoking just one cigarette raises your blood pressure, makes your heart work harder, increases your risk for blood clots and dangerous "extra" heartbeats, and may narrow your coronary arteries.

data.name: L1273
data.value: Smoking lowers your HDL or "good" cholesterol.

data.name: L1274
data.value: Smoking increases the risk for amputations in people with diabetes.

data.name: L1275
data.value: Women who take "the pill" and also smoke cigarettes are especially at a higher risk of heart attack and stroke.

data.name: L1276
data.value: Second-hand smoke causes about 10 times as many cardiovascular deaths as cancer deaths.

data.name: L1277
data.value: Children of smokers have many more respiratory infections than children of non-smokers.

data.name: L1278
data.value: Non-smoking women exposed to tobacco smoke during pregnancy are more likely to have low-birth weight babies.

data.name: L1279
data.value: No matter how much or how long you’ve smoked, when you quit, your risk of heart disease goes down.

data.name: L128
data.value: PSA test for prostate cancer during the past three years

data.name: L1280
data.value: There is no one best way to quit smoking. Techniques that have been successful in helping others quit smoking include:

data.name: L1281
data.value: Set a quit date. Start by setting a date you will quit. Mark it on your calendar. Give yourself plenty of time to get ready to quit, but plan to quit within the next 30 days. When setting a quit date, choose a date that doesn’t conflict with another stressful event, if possible. Some people like to quit on Monday. They use the weekend for final preparations to quit. Remember, any day is a good day to quit smoking!

data.name: L1282
data.value: Plan ways to avoid smoking. Don’t even think about substituting other tobacco products, such as cigars, pipes, or smokeless tobacco for cigarettes. Smoking cigars or pipes is harmful too. Like smoking, dipping or chewing has serious health effects, including oral cancer, gum problems, loss of teeth, and heart problems. If you plan to use a nicotine substitute, such as nicotine gum or a patch, and/or the prescription medication, bupropion, ask a health professional for additional information and guidance.

data.name: L1283
data.value: Involve others in your plan to quit. Your friends, family, and co-workers can be helpful and supportive as you are trying to quit. Seriously consider enrolling in a formal smoking cessation program.

data.name: L1284
data.value: Prepare for quit day. Some people find it helpful to gradually reduce their smoking rather than quitting "cold turkey." For example, during the weeks before your quit date, reduce the number of cigarettes you smoke by 25 percent each week (for example, instead of 20, smoke 15, then 10, then 5).

data.name: L1285
data.value: Develop your personal contract to quit smoking. Develop a specific plan to quit smoking. Research shows that people who put their plan in writing and ask someone to witness it are more committed to their goal and more likely to succeed.

data.name: L1286
data.value: Learn to wait for the urge to pass. Research shows the physical urge to smoke only lasts a few minutes at a time. Think of the urge as a wave that builds, crests, and then drops off suddenly. If you can ride the wave for a few minutes, it will go away. Focus on not smoking for five minutes at a time. After three or four five-minute periods, the physical urge will go away. And, the next urge will last even a shorter time period.

data.name: L1287
data.value: Build confidence to stay smoke free. Tobacco withdrawal symptoms may begin almost immediately after you stop smoking. They may include cravings, anxiety, irritability, restlessness, mood changes, nervousness, drowsiness, sleep disturbances, headaches, or digestive changes. Withdrawal symptoms are usually worst during the first three or four days. After two weeks, your physical symptoms of nicotine withdrawal should go away. That doesn’t mean, however, that you won’t want to smoke. The behavior (habit) of smoking takes longer to break. Remember, when it comes to cigarette smoking there is no such thing as moderation - even a single cigarette is harmful to you.

data.name: L1308
data.value: If you use smokeless tobacco long term, you have many of these very same risks. You also have a 50 times greater risk for oral cancer. Oral cancer includes cancer of the lip, tongue, cheeks, gums, and the floor and roof of the mouth. People who use oral snuff for a long time have a much greater risk for cancer of the cheek and gum than people who do not use smokeless tobacco.

data.name: L1309
data.value: There are numerous harmful chemicals and substances in smokeless tobacco. Chewing tobacco and snuff contain at least 28 cancer-causing agents or "carcinogens". All tobacco, including smokeless tobacco, contains nicotine. Unfortunately, nicotine is extremely addictive. Moreover, the amount of nicotine absorbed from smokeless tobacco is 3 to 4 times more than the amount delivered by a cigarette. Nicotine is absorbed more slowly from smokeless tobacco, but more nicotine per "dose" is absorbed from smokeless tobacco than from cigarettes. Also, the nicotine from smokeless tobacco stays in the bloodstream for a longer time.

data.name: L131
data.value: Dental exam during the past 12 months

data.name: L1310
data.value: In 1986, the Surgeon General concluded that the use of smokeless tobacco "is not a safe substitute for smoking cigarettes". Since 1991, the National Cancer Institute in the US has officially recommended that the public avoid and discontinue the use of all tobacco products, including smokeless tobacco.

data.name: L1311
data.value: No matter how much or how long you’ve used smokeless tobacco, when you quit, many of your health-risks go down.

data.name: L1312
data.value: There is no one best way to quit using smokeless tobacco. Techniques that have been successful in helping others quit include:

data.name: L1313
data.value: Set a quit date. Start by setting a date you will quit. Mark it on your calendar. Give yourself plenty of time to get ready to quit, but plan to quit within the next 30 days. When setting a quit date, choose a date that doesn’t conflict with another stressful event, if possible. Some people like to quit on Monday. They use the weekend for final preparations to quit. Remember, any day is a good day to quit using smokeless tobacco.

data.name: L1314
data.value: Plan ways to avoid smokeless tobacco. Don’t even think about substituting other tobacco products, such as cigarettes, cigars or pipes for smokeless tobacco. If you plan to use a nicotine substitute, such as nicotine gum or a patch, ask a health professional for additional information and guidance.

data.name: L1315
data.value: Involve others in your plan to quit. Your friends, family, and co-workers can be helpful and supportive as you are trying to quit. Seriously consider enrolling in a formal tobacco cessation program.

data.name: L1316
data.value: Prepare for quit day. Some people find it helpful to gradually reduce their use of smokeless tobacco rather than quitting "cold turkey." For example, during the weeks before your quit date, reduce the amount you use by 25 percent each week.

data.name: L1317
data.value: Develop your personal contract to quit using smokeless tobacco. Develop a specific plan to quit. Research shows that people who put their plan in writing and ask someone to witness it are more committed to their goal and more likely to succeed.

data.name: L1318
data.value: Learn to wait for the urge to pass. Research shows the physical urge to use tobacco only lasts a few minutes at a time. Think of the urge as a wave that builds, crests, and then drops off suddenly. If you can ride the wave for a few minutes, it will go away. Focus on not using tobacco for five minutes at a time. After three or four five-minute periods, the physical urge will go away. And, the next urge will last even a shorter time period.

data.name: L1319
data.value: Build confidence to stay tobacco free. Tobacco withdrawal symptoms may begin almost immediately after you stop using smokeless tobacco. They may include cravings, anxiety, irritability, restlessness, mood changes, nervousness, drowsiness, sleep disturbances, headaches, or digestive changes. Withdrawal symptoms are usually worst during the first three or four days. After two weeks, your physical symptoms of nicotine withdrawal should go away. That doesn’t mean, however, that you won’t want to use tobacco. The behavior (habit) of using tobacco takes longer to break. Remember, when it comes to tobacco use, there is no such thing as moderation - even small amounts are harmful to you.

data.value: You may benefit from "high-intensity" treatment with a class of cholesterol-lowering drugs called "statins" (based on recommendations from the American College of Cardiology and American Heart Association in the November 2018 issues of the Journal of the American College of Cardiology and Circulation). Please discuss this with your doctor if you have not already recently done so and/or are not currently taking high-intensity statin treatment. Note: "High-intensity" means a statin dose that lowers LDL cholesterol on average by approximately 50 percent or more; if you are uncertain whether you are currently taking high-intensity statin treatment, please check with your doctor or health coach.

data.name: L1736
data.value: Myintervent.com, interventint.com, interventhealth.com, and all other sites that include the "intervent" name ("Site" or "Sites") are Internet-based online services owned and operated by INTERVENT INTERNATIONAL, LLC ("INTERVENT") that provide (a) access to the INTERVENT scientifically-based assessments, programs and products for the prevention and management of cardiovascular and other chronic diseases (the "Products"), (b) information regarding wellness and disease management (the "Information"), and (c) communication services related to wellness and disease management topics ("Communication Services" and, collectively with the Products and Information, the "Services") to users of a Site ("User" or "Users"). INTERVENT is a company that specializes in (a) scientifically-based assessments, programs and products for the prevention and management of cardiovascular and other chronic diseases, (b) information regarding wellness, lifestyle management and disease management, and (c) communication services related to wellness, lifestyle management and disease management topics. BY ACCESSING OR USING a Site or the Products or Services, YOU AGREE TO BE BOUND BY THE TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF THIS AGREEMENT (the "Agreement"). IF YOU DO NOT WISH TO BE BOUND BY THIS Agreement, YOU MAY NOT ACCESS OR USE a Site. INTERVENT MAY MODIFY THIS Agreement AT ANY TIME, AND SUCH MODIFICATION SHALL BE EFFECTIVE IMMEDIATELY UPON EITHER POSTING OF THE MODIFIED Agreement OR NOTIFYING YOU. YOU AGREE TO REVIEW THIS AGREEMENT PERIODICALLY TO ENSURE THAT YOU ARE AWARE OF ANY MODIFICATIONS. YOUR CONTINUED ACCESS OR USE OF a Site SHALL BE DEEMED YOUR CONCLUSIVE ACCEPTANCE OF THE MODIFIED Agreement

data.name: L1737
data.value: The Services are presented for the purpose of educating Users on wellness, lifestyle and disease management topics. Neither INTERVENT nor the Sites directly or indirectly practice medicine or dispense medical services. Nothing contained in the Sites or the Services is intended to be for medical diagnosis or treatment of any nature and especially regarding prevention of cardiovascular and other chronic diseases. The Services should not be considered complete, nor should they be relied on to suggest a course of medical treatment for a particular individual, which can only be provided by a physician or other qualified health care provider (generally referred to herein as a "physician"). The Services should not be used as a substitute for or in place of a visit or call to, consultation with, or the advice of your physician. The Services are not exhaustive and do not cover all wellness topics, diseases, ailments, and physical conditions or their treatment. Should you have any changes in your medical condition or health care-related questions, please call or see your physician promptly. We expect that you will consult with your physician before embarking on a new treatment, diet, or fitness program, including use of the Services. You should never disregard or discontinue following medical advice or delay in seeking it because of the Information, the Communication Services, or use of the Products or Services. The Information is compiled from, and the Products are based upon, a variety of sources, including nationally accepted guidelines of organizations such as the American College of Cardiology, American Heart Association, American College of Sports Medicine, National Institutes of Health, American Association of Cardiovascular and Pulmonary Rehabilitation, and U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (the "Guideline Organizations"). In no way, however, have the Services been reviewed or approved by the Guideline Organizations. In addition, INTERVENT makes use of scientific advisors to aid in making scientific related decisions, but the Services should not be interpreted as reflecting scientific certainty

data.name: L1755
data.value: Purpose and explanation of the INTERVENT Services

data.name: L1756
data.value: The Services have been developed with input from physicians and other experienced health care professionals. In some cases, the Services are supervised and/or administered by non-physician staff members. However, I understand that the Services are not medical care nor are they intended as a replacement for my regular medical care and that the staff does not provide medical treatment or prescribe medications. I acknowledge that during my participation in or use of the Services my physician remains responsible for my medical care

data.name: L1757
data.value: I hereby affirm that I am voluntarily engaging in the INTERVENT Services selected by me. I understand that some of the INTERVENT Services are not intended for pregnant women and affirm that, if I am female, I am not pregnant or have informed the INTERVENT staff that I am pregnant. These Services are intended, but not guaranteed, to improve my health and well-being and may include exercise and physical activity recommendations, dietary counseling, stress management, smoking cessation and other health/fitness education activities. I will be given instructions regarding the amount and kind of exercise and physical activity I should engage in. I understand that I may be expected to participate in scheduled activities and am expected to follow instructions with regard to exercise and physical activity, diet, stress management, and other health/fitness-related activities, including communications with my physician. If I am taking prescribed medications, I will inform INTERVENT. If I participate in or use a Product supervised by an INTERVENT staff member, I will inform INTERVENT promptly of any changes in my condition (including if I am female and become pregnant) or any changes that my physician or I make with regard to use of medications. I also agree to provide my physician with copies of reports I am provided by the Sites or the Services. Depending on the Product I select, I may be given the opportunity for periodic assessment and evaluation at regular intervals after the start of my participation in or use of the Product. I understand that I can request to speak with a supervisor or manager to provide feedback specific to my experience with the Services or the Sites

data.name: L1758
data.value: I acknowledge that I may have selected a Product from INTERVENT that includes assistance from and scheduled interactions with trained personnel with health backgrounds to provide general direction of my activities, monitor my performance and otherwise evaluate my progress. Otherwise, I realize that no one other than me and possibly my physician will direct my activities, monitor my performance or otherwise evaluate my progress. In such event, I accept full responsibility for these activities and for independently following or choosing not to follow the recommendations made to me by INTERVENT or from the Sites

data.name: L1759
data.value: I have been informed that during my participation in the Services, I will be asked to engage in physical activity unless symptoms such as excessive fatigue, shortness of breath, light headedness, palpitations, chest discomfort, or similar occurrences appear. If these or any other untoward symptoms occur, I have been advised that I should decrease or stop exercise and physical activity immediately and that it is my obligation to inform my physician of my symptoms before continuing with additional physical activities. I hereby affirm that I have been so advised and agree to inform my physician of my symptoms, should any develop

data.name: L1760
data.value: INTERVENT may have reason to contact you via your cell phone or regular telephone or via text message to your cell phone to make, or remind you of, appointments, to provide motivational information, to provide program updates, to inform you if you need to see your doctor, and/or to provide other services that we believe may be of importance to you. By submitting this form, you are giving us your consent to use automated technology to call or text you at the phone number(s), including your wireless number, that you provide to us. data.name: L1762
data.value: I understand and have been informed that there is a remote possibility of adverse changes occurring during exercise and physical activity including, but not limited to, abnormal blood pressure, fainting, dizziness, disorders of heart rhythm, and very rare instances of heart attack, stroke, or even death. I further understand and I have been informed that the risk of bodily injury exists including, but not limited to, injuries to the muscles, ligaments, tendons, and joints of the body. I have been told that efforts will be made to minimize these occurrences by the provision of scientifically-based, individualized exercise and physical activity recommendations together with an opportunity for regular assessments of my progress and on-going revision of my exercise and physical activity recommendations if I participate in or use a Product supervised by an INTERVENT staff member. Also, I will follow my exercise and physical activity recommendations, record the details in my exercise diary and report any untoward situations to my physician and to INTERVENT

data.name: L1763
data.value: I further understand that there may be risks associated with making dietary changes, such as an increased risk for gallstones and, for persons with diabetes, fluctuations in blood sugar levels. I fully understand the risks associated with exercise and physical activity and dietary changes, including the risk of bodily injury, heart attack, stroke, coma, or even death, but knowing these risks, it is my desire to participate as herein indicated

data.name: L1815
data.value: At INTERVENT, protecting your privacy is crucial. We know you are interested in how we collect, use, share and protect your information. We will treat your information responsibly and provide you with choices about how we use and share it.

data.name: L1816
data.value: If we change our privacy policy, we will post the changes right here.

data.name: L1817
data.value: We most recently updated our posted Privacy Policy on October 22, 2012.

data.name: L1818
data.value: Collecting, using, and sharing visitor information

data.name: L1819
data.value: Many of our online activities do not require visitors to our Site to register for an account or give us any Personal Information. For example, visitors can learn about our broad range of programs without giving us any Personal Information, like a name or address. However, INTERVENT and our business partners are still interested in who visits our site and how they use it. We use cookies so we can improve your online experience. Cookies also track visitors’ IP addresses, domain names and browser information. They do not collect a visitor’s Personal Information, but they help us to:

data.name: L1820
data.value: Analyze how visitors use our Site

data.name: L1821
data.value: Develop new services to improve our Site

data.name: L1823
data.value: Know how many visitors have seen or clicked on ads

data.name: L1825
data.value: When you visit www.myintervent.com and other INTERVENT Sites, we send a cookie to your computer’s hard drive. Cookies are small files recorded by your Internet browser that retain information about your Site visits. We use two types of cookies, namely, session, and persistent cookies. They help us to identify your browser, to remember your web preferences and to recognize you when you move from page to page within our Site. Cookies and similar files that we place on your computer do not contain any Personal Information unless it is encrypted. You can configure your Internet browser to reject (disable) cookies. However, if you do so, you might not be able to access certain pages or use important functions on the Site.

data.name: L1826
data.value: INTERVENT uses cookies in different ways:

data.name: L1828
data.value: We may place these types of cookies on your hard drive to help with web navigation. Session cookies also help to personalize your experience while visiting our site, to gather data about the usage of our site and to track response to an advertisement. We erase web browsing cookies when you close your browser. They do not contain or capture customer-specific data.

data.name: L1830
data.value: INTERVENT also uses persistent cookies that are saved on your computer after you end your visit to our site. They allow us to identify your preferences and enhance your next visit to our Site. Any time a persistent cookie is used, your Personal Information is encrypted and used solely to support your online activity.

data.name: L1833
data.value: Visitors can choose to use site surveys and other tools to tell us what they think about our site. We collect and use the comments that visitors provide to improve your experience on our site.

data.name: L1835
data.value: INTERVENT may use business partners to help develop, service, or advertise our Sites, including the App. They may track and keep visitor information.

data.name: L1836
data.value: Collecting and using your Personal Information

data.name: L1837
data.value: Personal Information is any information that identifies you and describes your relationship with INTERVENT. Some examples of the information that we may collect include:

data.name: L1839
data.value: Social Security number or other identification number

data.name: L1841
data.value: Health/Medical information and medical history, including information from health and fitness devices that I use and have linked to the Site

data.name: L1844
data.value: We require you to share your Personal Information with us for some of our online and other activities and Services. For example, we may collect your Personal Information so you can access your information, enroll and participate in programs, and ask us questions. We collect your Personal Information from the online questionnaire or via any follow-up communications we may have with you, such as when you:

data.name: L1851
data.value: Subscribe to receive email from us

data.name: L1852
data.value: We assign you a username and password (that you may later change) so that you may continue to securely access your specific information when you return to the Site.

data.name: L1853
data.value: We also use Personal Information to allow you to participate in Services. In particular, we use Personal Information for the following purposes: to conduct cardiovascular disease and related risk assessments, to make recommendations regarding how you might reduce or manage any risk(s) associated with such assessments (e.g., recommendations regarding blood pressure and cholesterol management, weight management and nutrition, smoking cessation and stress management), and to communicate with you regarding such assessments and recommendations. We also may use Personal Information for secondary purposes of internal research, studies, related statistical analysis, and to design and improve the services we offer. We will not disclose Personal Information related to such secondary purposes. We may use, disclose, and otherwise process for any purpose all information that is not in personally identifiable form (i.e., anonymous data).

data.name: L1854
data.value: Access to Personal Information is restricted to those employees, contractors or agents of INTERVENT who need such access to administer or assist INTERVENT to administer the Services.

data.name: L1855
data.value: Personal Information also may be disclosed, where permitted by applicable law, in connection with a corporate restructuring, sale, or assignment of assets, merger, divestiture, or other changes of the financial status of INTERVENT or any of our subsidiary or affiliated companies. Personal Information also may be disclosed to third parties, in accordance with applicable law, to protect your vital interests, to protect the rights of INTERVENT or others, or in INTERVENT’s good faith judgment to comply with applicable law, law enforcement investigations, or court orders.

data.name: L1856
data.value: You may choose to use your personal email to correspond with INTERVENT. Please be careful about the information you send to us in email. As with any public web tool, your email may not be secure; so please do not include sensitive information.

data.name: L1857

data.name: L1858
data.value: IF YOUR USE OF THE SITE IS OFFERED TO YOU BY AN EMPLOYER, THE FOLLOWING ADDED PROVISIONS AND NOTIFICATIONS SHALL APPLY:

data.name: L1859
data.value: YOUR EMPLOYER (OR THE EMPLOYER OF YOUR SPOUSE, PARTNER OR FAMILY MEMBER) MAY HAVE ALLOWED YOU TO USE THE HEALTH MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS AND SERVICES ("SERVICES") DESCRIBED ON THIS SITE AND MAY HAVE PROVIDED US WITH YOUR ELIGIBILITY INFORMATION. YOUR PARTICIPATION IN THE SERVICES IS COMPLETELY VOLUNTARY, BUT IF YOU DO PARTICIPATE, WE WILL NEED TO COLLECT YOUR PERSONAL INFORMATION TO ALLOW YOU TO USE THE SERVICES.

data.name: L1860
data.value: AT THE DIRECTION OF YOUR EMPLOYER AND IN ACCORDANCE WITH APPROPRIATE REGULATIONS, WE MAY DISCLOSE YOUR PERSONAL INFORMATION TO CONTRACTORS, AGENTS OR DATA PROCESSORS THAT WORK WITH YOUR EMPLOYER. SUCH USES MAY INCLUDE SHARING YOUR NON-PERSONALLY IDENTIFIABLE INFORMATION ON A CONFIDENTIAL BASIS WITH A DATA WAREHOUSE FOR ANALYSIS OF HEALTH TRENDS AND EFFECTIVENESS OF HEALTH PROGRAMS OR WITH OTHER THIRD PARTY SERVICE PROVIDERS, INCLUDING THOSE ASSOCIATED WITH YOUR EMPLOYER OR HEALTH PLAN THAT HELP YOUR EMPLOYER MANAGE THE QUALITY AND COST OF THE SERVICES.

data.name: L1861
data.value:
WE WILL NOT SHARE ANY MEDICAL, HEALTH, OR RELATED PERSONAL INFORMATION DIRECTLY WITH YOUR EMPLOYER.

FOR SOME OF OUR EMPLOYER SPONSORED PROGRAMS, WE ARE REQUIRED TO SHARE LIMITED INFORMATION WITH YOUR HEALTH PLAN OR YOUR EMPLOYER’S DESIGNEES WHO ADMINISTER HEALTH AND WELLNESS PROGRAMS. INTERVENT MAY ADVISE PLANS WHETHER YOU HAVE CHOSEN TO PARTICIPATE IN: CARE, DISEASE OR MATERNITY MANAGEMENT, OR WELLNESS AND HEALTH PROMOTION PROGRAMS AND WHETHER YOU QUALIFY FOR INCENTIVES, IF OFFERED BY THE PLAN.

data.name: L1862
data.value: WE MAY SHARE LIMITED PERSONAL INFORMATION ABOUT YOU WITH YOUR EMPLOYER CONSISTING OF YOUR NAME AND CONTACT INFORMATION ONLY. WE SHARE THIS INFORMATION WITH EMPLOYERS PRIMARILY FOR THE PURPOSES OF TRACKING THE NUMBER OF PARTICIPANTS ENROLLED, PAYMENT AND ADMINISTRATIVE PURPOSES, INCLUDING PROVIDING INCENTIVES FOR PARTICIPATION FROM YOUR EMPLOYER.

data.name: L1864
data.value: We do not sell your Personal Information.

data.name: L1865
data.value: Sharing your Personal Information for marketing

data.name: L1866
data.value: WE DO NOT SELL YOUR PERSONAL INFORMATION FOR MARKETING PURPOSES. EXCEPT AS DISCLOSED ABOVE, WE DO NOT SHARE YOUR PERSONAL INFORMATION WITH ANYONE EXCEPT TO DELIVER OUR PROGRAM, AS OUTLINED. SO, THERE IS NO REASON FOR YOU TO OPT OUT. IF WE CHANGE OUR POLICY, WE WILL TELL YOU AND GIVE YOU AN OPPORTUNITY TO OPT OUT BEFORE WE SHARE YOUR INFORMATION.

data.name: L1867
data.value: Data located in the United States

data.name: L1868
data.value: The Site is hosted on servers located in the United States. The telephone call centers supporting the Site are also located in the United States. All Services-related analyses of the Personal Information you provide will be performed by INTERVENT employees or agents using servers in the United States. Therefore, if you reside or work outside the United States, the Personal Information that you provide via your computer may be transferred to the United States, a jurisdiction where the privacy laws might not provide a level of protection to Personal Information that is equivalent to that of the laws of your home jurisdiction or jurisdiction in which you are located. This does not change any of our commitments to safeguard your privacy.

data.name: L1870
data.value: We maintain technical, electronic, and organizational procedures to maintain the security of Personal Information, and safeguard Personal Information against unauthorized or unlawful processing and/or against accidental loss, alteration, disclosure or access. Our security procedures include contractual terms with any contractors, agents or data processors to ensure that such entities protect the security and confidentiality of Personal Information in accordance with our standards and applicable laws and regulations.

data.name: L1871
data.value: We limit access to your Personal Information to those who need it to do their jobs. The law requires our business partners to use your Personal Information only for our purposes. They may not share it or use it in any other way. We comply with all data security laws.

data.name: L1872
data.value: It is your responsibility to safeguard any username or password that you have received in connection with the Site, and to notify us if you ever suspect that the security and confidentiality of such username or password has been compromised in any way. You are solely responsible for any use of this Site via your username and password.

data.name: L1874
data.value: We will maintain Personal Information for as long as we are required to do so by applicable law(s), or for as long as necessary for the purpose(s) for which it is collected, used, or processed as outlined above. We will delete Personal Information when it is no longer needed for a purpose related to its collection or use or upon expiration of the storage term set forth by applicable law.

data.name: L1876
data.value: Other companies or organizations may have links to their websites on our web pages. We are not responsible for how they collect, use, disclose or secure the information that you provide to them. Please read their privacy policies so you can learn how their website uses your information.

data.name: L1878
data.value: Where required by applicable law, you are generally entitled to update or access Personal Information that we hold about you. In most circumstances, you may do so via the Site or by contacting us at info@myintervent.com. Requested copies of your Personal Information will be provided in a reasonable period. If there is a charge for the cost of producing a copy, we will advise you of the cost in advance of processing your request.

data.name: L1879
data.value: We have a process that allows you to review your information after we have verified your identity. Please note that we can only give you access to, correct or update Personal Information that we control.

data.name: L1880
data.value: These are our privacy practices. They apply to all current and former clients of INTERVENT.

data.name: L1904
data.value: The foods you eat, the stress you feel and the activities you do all affect your health. Now you can find out how by completing our health risk assessment (HRA)

data.name: L1905
data.value: The HRA is a free confidential online assessment that considers your lifestyle habits and health history to determine how healthy you are and whether you’re at risk for certain chronic diseases or illnesses. It only takes about 15 minutes to complete

data.name: L1906
data.value: Once you complete the HRA you will immediately receive a great personal report, health roadmap and a wealth of useful information individually tailored for you. Plus, you’ll be able to take advantage of our lifestyle management programs where you can learn about how to eat more healthfully, manage your weight, reduce your stress level and much more

Please discuss this with your doctor if you have not already recently done so and/or are not currently taking high-intensity statin treatment. Note: "High-intensity" means a statin dose that lowers LDL cholesterol on average by approximately 50 percent or more; if you are uncertain whether you are currently taking high-intensity statin treatment, please check with your doctor.

data.name: L1962

data.name: L1993
data.value: The coronary arteries supply the heart with oxygen rich blood. Atherosclerosis is the process by which cholesterol-rich plaque builds up in the walls of the coronary arteries. Over time, atherosclerotic plaque can cause blockages or narrowings in the coronary arteries. This limits the flow of oxygen-rich blood to the heart muscle and can cause a heart attack.

data.name: L1994
data.value: Normal coronary arteries do not contain calcium. Atherosclerotic plaque does contain calcium. Calcium in the coronary arteries may be a sign of plaque build-up and an increased risk for a heart attack.

data.name: L1995
data.value: Calcium in the coronary arteries can be evaluated by performing a heart scan test. Your test results includes a number that is called your coronary artery calcium (CAC) score. CAC scores can range from 0 to more than 400. The higher your CAC score, the greater your likelihood of having atherosclerotic plaque in your coronary arteries and the higher your chances of having a heart attack.

data.name: L1999
data.value: Based on your test results, you have no identifiable atherosclerotic plaque in your heart’s coronary arteries. While a zero score does not absolutely rule out the presence of atherosclerotic plaque, the chances that you have narrowings in your coronary arteries are very low. Please discuss your CAC report with your doctor as soon as possible (if you have not already done so).

data.name: L2000

While a zero score is optimal, it is very unlikely that you have narrowings in your coronary arteries. Please discuss your CAC report with your doctor as soon as possible (if you have not already done so).

data.name: L2001
data.value: Based on your test results, you have definite, at least mild, atherosclerotic plaque in your heart’s coronary arteries. Mild or minimal coronary artery narrowings are likely to be present. Please discuss your CAC report with your doctor as soon as possible (if you have not already done so).

data.name: L2002
data.value: Based on your test results, you have definite, at least moderate, atherosclerotic plaque in your heart’s coronary arteries. Mild coronary artery narrowings are highly likely to be present and significant narrowings may possibly be present. Please discuss your CAC report with your doctor as soon as possible (if you have not already done so).

data.name: L2003

Please discuss your CAC report with your doctor as soon as possible (if you have not already done so).

data.name: L2053
data.value: You are the most important member of your health care team. With help from your McAllen Heart Hospital team and INTERVENT, you can achieve your lifestyle management and cardiac risk reduction goals and change the course of your life.

data.name: L2054
data.value: What Is Cardiac Score CT Screening?

data.name: L2055
data.value: A Few Minutes Now Could Save Your Life

data.name: L2056
data.value: Cardiac Score CT Screening is a convenient, noninvasive test that evaluates whether you are at an increased risk of a heart attack. The scans are painless, have no side effects and typically take seven minutes to complete.

data.name: L2057
data.value: Cardiac CT Scans determine the amount of calcium in a coronary artery, which in turn indicates the amount of fatty deposits (or "plaque") in a blood vessel. These calcium deposits typically appear years before a person shows signs of heart disease, such as chest pain or shortness of breath. Specialized computer software is used to calculate a calcium score for each of your coronary arteries based on the volume and density of calcium present.

data.name: L2058
data.value: Calcium scores help physicians assess a patient’s risk of developing heart problems. Scans can also measure the progression of heart disease and the effectiveness of treatment.

data.name: L2059
data.value: The INTERVENT health assessment is an online assessment that considers your lifestyle habits, health history, calcium score and other measures to determine your arterial age, your heart disease risk factors and your risk for certain other chronic conditions. It only takes about 15 minutes to complete. The results are used to set appropriate goals for you.

data.name: L2060
data.value: A McAllen Heart Hospital care team member will review your personal report with you and suggest a roadmap for improving your health. Plus, if you like, you’ll be able to enroll in our CardioSmart OnCall telephonic coaching program to learn about how to eat healthfully, be physically active, manage your weight, manage your stress, sleep better and much more.

data.name: L600
data.value: In most industrialized countries, more adults die from cardiovascular disease each year than from AIDS, cancer, accidents, lung diseases, and influenza combined. Of the various types of cardiovascular disease, coronary heart disease, the disease causing heart attacks, causes the most deaths.

data.name: L601
data.value: Coronary heart disease occurs when blockages, called atherosclerotic plaque, build up inside the coronary arteries. Blockages begin to build up inside our coronary arteries during childhood. As we age, the blockages progressively get worse and ultimately may trigger a heart attack or sudden death.

data.name: L602
data.value: There is currently no cure for coronary heart disease -- not medications, not angioplasty, not bypass surgery. If you have coronary heart disease, it is likely to get worse unless you do something to change or manage certain conditions or behaviors, called risk factors.

data.name: L603
data.value: But there is good news! One of the most exciting discoveries in medicine in recent years is that it is possible to slow down the build-up of blockages inside coronary arteries. It is even possible to cause existing blockages to be partially removed. This process is called reversal of coronary heart disease and it results from risk factor modification.

data.name: L604
data.value: The major risk factors for coronary heart disease are:

data.name: L616
data.value: Stroke is a leading cause of death and serious, long-term disability. Although more common among seniors, over 25 percent of stroke victims are under age 65.

data.name: L617
data.value: A stroke occurs as a result of an interruption in the blood supply to part of the brain. All tissues and organs in your body need oxygen-rich blood and fuel to survive, but your brain is especially vulnerable. It’s the control center of your body, directing every thought and physical action. When something goes wrong in the brain, the result is immediate, serious, and can be potentially fatal.

data.name: L618
data.value: In the case of a "mini-stroke" or TIA (transient ischemic attack), the interruption of blood flow to the brain is brief, causing the cells to pause in their normal functioning for only a few minutes or hours. Once the blood flow is restored, those cells begin to revive and normal body functions return. TIAs are often called stroke warning spells because they can happen before a major stroke.

data.name: L619
data.value: The best way to treat a stroke is to prevent it from happening in the first place or recurring a second time. In addition to the early recognition of stroke warning signs, like heart disease, a key to stroke prevention is risk factor modification. The major risk factors for heart disease are also important risk factors for stroke. Think of a stroke as a "brain attack" rather than a "heart attack."

data.name: L62
data.value: During the {0}, have you performed regular moderate- and/or vigorous-intensity aerobic physical activity (that is, the equivalent of at least a brisk walk) for at least 30 minutes on at least three days each week?

data.name: L620
data.value: Like heart disease, lifestyle changes are particularly helpful in reducing stroke risk stemming from high blood pressure, high cholesterol, physical inactivity, excess weight, diabetes, or smoking.

data.name: L622
data.value: You may experience any or all of these symptoms. Sometimes the symptoms go away then come back again.

data.name: L623
data.value: Uncomfortable pressure, fullness, squeezing, or pain in the center of the chest lasting more than a few minutes

data.name: L624

data.name: L625

data.name: L626
data.value: If you experience any of the above symptoms for more than 15 minutes, get help immediately.

data.name: L630
data.value: Most of the damage occurring from a heart attack occurs within the first six hours. The faster you can get help, the greater the chance of limited damage to your heart and a quick and complete recovery.

data.name: L641
data.value: My Warning Signs to be Aware of - Stroke

data.name: L642
data.value: Knowing the warning signs of stroke is important. If you act fast and see a doctor immediately, you could prevent a major stroke or save your life. You and your family should learn these warning signs of stroke. You may have one or several of them. They may last for just a few seconds.

data.name: L643
data.value: Paralysis, sudden weakness, clumsiness, or loss of sensation in an arm, leg, or the side of your face. You may experience a single symptom in one place or most of these symptoms in several places on the body.

data.name: L644
data.value: Rapid onset of blurred or decreased vision, especially in one eye.

data.name: L645
data.value: Loss of speech or difficulty in speaking or in understanding what others are saying.

data.name: L646
data.value: Loss of balance, dizziness, unsteadiness, or difficulty in swallowing.

data.name: L647
data.value: A TIA, sometimes called a mini-stroke, happens fast and is over quickly, usually lasting for more than two minutes but less than 15 minutes. The symptoms of a TIA are the same symptoms that accompany a full-fledged stroke. If you experience any of these symptoms, don’t try to figure out whether you’re having a TIA or a stroke. Get emergency medical treatment immediately. Prompt action may save your life or help limit the damage to your brain.

data.name: L648
data.value: Some strokes occur due to bleeding in or around the brain. These types of stroke give little warning and are seldom preceded by a TIA. By the time you feel the symptoms, you’re having the stroke. Urgent medical care is needed. In addition to the above mentioned symptoms, these symptoms may occur:

Note: "Unhealthy" fats (saturated and trans fats) and cholesterol are found in foods such as fatty meats; whole milk dairy products; butter, lard and stick margarine; coconut and palm oils; many fast foods; many commercially-prepared baked goods; many fried foods; regular peanut butter; egg yolks; and organ meats.

data.name: L670
data.value: High blood pressure, also known as hypertension, is called the "silent killer" because its victims often die without knowing they had a problem. High blood pressure causes your heart to work extra hard to pump blood through your body. Two numbers, systolic (top) and diastolic (bottom), describe your blood pressure, and it is important to know both. Systolic pressure is the pressure inside your arteries when your heart contracts and pumps blood into your arteries. Diastolic pressure is the pressure inside your arteries when your heart relaxes and fills with blood.

data.name: L671
data.value: High blood pressure (or hypertension) is generally defined as systolic values of 130 or higher and/or diastolic values of 80 or higher. When the systolic value is 120 to 129 and the diastolic value is less than 80, you have what is referred to as elevated blood pressure. The higher your blood pressure, the higher your risk for heart attack, stroke, heart failure, kidney failure, and eye problems.

data.name: L672
data.value: Classification of Blood Pressure for Adults (18 Years and Older)

data.name: L68
data.value: Do you drink more than an average of one alcoholic drink each day (1 drink=12 oz or 360 mL beer, 5 oz or 150 mL wine or 1.5 oz or 45 mL liquor)?

data.name: L688
data.value: Source: Guideline for the Prevention, Detection, Evaluation, and Management of High Blood Pressure in Adults: A Report of the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Task Force on Clinical Practice Guidelines, November 2017.

data.name: L689
data.value: In over 90 percent of people with high blood pressure, the precise cause is unknown. In these individuals, genetics is thought to play an important role. Even if you are likely to have high blood pressure for genetic reasons, you can lower your blood pressure or prevent it from getting high through lifestyle changes, especially:

data.name: L691
data.value: Losing weight if you are overweight and keeping it off

data.name: L692
data.value: Reducing the amount of sodium (salt) you eat

data.name: L693
data.value: Not drinking alcohol or drinking only in moderation

data.name: L694
data.value: There are also safe and effective medications to help control high blood pressure. Drug therapy works best when used in combination with lifestyle changes.

data.name: L701
data.value: My Basic Information – Cholesterol and Triglycerides

data.name: L702
data.value: High blood cholesterol, along with cigarette smoking, high blood pressure, physical inactivity, and obesity, is one of the five major risk factors for coronary heart disease. High cholesterol also increases your risk for strokes. Triglycerides, another type of fat in the blood, also contribute to heart disease.

data.name: L703
data.value: There are two major types of cholesterol: LDL (low density lipoprotein or "bad" cholesterol) and HDL (high density lipoprotein or "good" cholesterol). Having too much LDL cholesterol or too little HDL cholesterol in your blood causes plaque to build up inside your coronary arteries and block the flow of blood to your heart muscle. Blockages can cause chest pain or angina, and plaques that rupture can cause blood clots to form and trigger heart attacks. Your level of HDL cholesterol can never be too high and the higher it is the lower your risk for coronary heart disease.

data.name: L704
data.value: A total blood cholesterol level under 200 mg/dl (or 5.2 mmol/L) is generally recommended. However, we believe it is more important to focus on LDL and HDL cholesterol than on your total cholesterol number. In some cases, looking at only the total cholesterol number is misleading. It is possible to have a normal total cholesterol level due to a high LDL cholesterol together with a low HDL cholesterol. But, a high LDL and a low HDL are bad and put you at risk for coronary heart disease. It is also possible to have a high total cholesterol level due to a high HDL cholesterol, which is good if your LDL cholesterol is low. In addition to LDL and HDL cholesterol, it is also important to keep your triglyceride levels in the desirable range.

data.name: L705
data.value: Generally, to get an accurate reading of LDL and triglycerides, you must fast for 8 to 12 hours before the blood sample is taken. Fasting means eating no food and drinking only water. In contrast, it is not necessary to fast to get accurate total cholesterol and HDL readings. If you don’t know your LDL and triglyceride levels, the next best thing is to calculate your "non-HDL cholesterol" value (by subtracting your HDL from your total cholesterol). Non-HDL cholesterol is also a better predictor of your risk for heart disease and stroke than your LDL value if your triglyceride level is 200 mg/dl (or 2.3 mmol/L) or higher. Lower non-HDL cholesterol values are associated with a reduced risk for heart disease and stroke.

data.name: L706
data.value: To help lower your LDL cholesterol and keep it at a healthy level:

data.name: L733
data.value: My Basic Information – Overweight and Obesity

data.name: L734
data.value: Overweight and obesity are a major public health problem. The chronic diseases associated with overweight and obesity are major killers. The increased risk of death is mainly due to heart disease. But, overweight and obesity also significantly increase the risk of developing type 2 diabetes, high blood pressure, stroke, high cholesterol and high triglycerides, osteoarthritis, gallbladder disease, sleep apnea, respiratory problems, and certain types of cancer.

data.name: L735
data.value: Body mass index (BMI) is the most widely accepted method of assessing body weight. BMI describes relative weight for height. It is calculated as weight in kilograms divided by the square of height in meters: weight (kg)/[height (m<sup>2</sup>)]. The National Institutes of Health and other expert groups use the BMI classifications provided below.

data.name: L74
data.value: Do you have any physical problems (such as a medical condition or injury) that you believe limits your ability to participate in regular physical activity?

data.name: L75

data.name: L750
data.value: Your BMI was calculated from your HRA measurements and used to help set your short-term and long-term body weight goals. If you are very muscular, these interpretations may not apply to you. Because muscle tissue is heavier than fat tissue, people who are very muscular may be falsely classified as overweight or even obese.

data.name: L751
data.value: Measuring your waist circumference is another way to evaluate your weight. Waist circumference is an indicator of how much fat is stored in the abdomen. There is evidence that increases in abdominal fat (out of proportion to total body fatness) are associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, type 2 diabetes, and high blood pressure. A high waist circumference can also be an indicator for increased risk even in people of normal weight. Cut-off points for waist circumferences associated with increased risk for chronic diseases are typically defined as follows:

data.name: L776
data.value: The metabolic syndrome was first identified in the 1980s. It is characterized by the presence of several specific risk factors for coronary heart disease in one person. People with the metabolic syndrome have a much higher risk of developing coronary heart disease (the cause of heart attacks and the number one killer of adults), stroke, and type 2 diabetes. They are also more likely to develop other conditions, such as polycystic ovary syndrome in women, certain types of liver disease, gallstones, asthma, sleep problems, and some cancers. Overall, the metabolic syndrome increases a person’s risk of early death to about the same degree as cigarette smoking.

data.name: L778
data.value: No single test can identify the metabolic syndrome. The U.S. National Cholesterol Education Program’s Adult Treatment Panel III (ATP III) established five features for the diagnosis of the metabolic syndrome. The precise definition of each criterion was updated by the American Heart Association and National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute in October 2005. Your health assessment evaluates all five features and reports your values for you.

data.name: L779
data.value: If you have any three or more of the metabolic risk factors presented in the table below, you have the metabolic syndrome.

data.name: L781
data.value: Defining Levels for the Metabolic Syndrome

data.name: L784

data.name: L785
data.value: Greater than 35 inches (88 cm) in women

data.name: L796
data.value: Fortunately, the metabolic syndrome is usually preventable and treatable with:

data.name: L799
data.value: Good risk factor management can help prevent people with the metabolic syndrome from developing coronary heart disease, type 2 diabetes, and other health problems. The greatest potential for prevention and treatment of the syndrome lies in reversing its root causes:
