data.name: L809
data.value: Diabetes is one of the most common chronic diseases. Diabetes cannot be cured, but it can be prevented and/or controlled. If you have diabetes, it is critical that you learn all you can about your diabetes.

data.name: L81
data.value: Do any of the following apply to you? (please check all that apply.)

data.name: L810
data.value: People with diabetes have problems regulating the amount of sugar or glucose in their blood. When left untreated, they have too much glucose in their blood. Once the amount of glucose in the blood exceeds a certain level, excess glucose spills over into the urine. Diabetes mellitus comes from the Greek word diabetes (to flow through; urine) and the Latin word mellitus (sweetened or honey-like).

data.name: L811
data.value: When you eat sugars and starches, the body changes them into a form of sugar called glucose. Glucose enters the blood and is carried to all of the cells of the body where it is ready to be used for energy. The hormone insulin, which is produced in the pancreas, is responsible for moving the glucose out of the blood and into the cells. Too much glucose in the blood, a condition known as hyper (high) glycemia (glucose), is dangerous and can cause damage to organs in the body.

data.name: L812
data.value: There are two main types of diabetes:

data.name: L813
data.value: Type 1 Diabetes – With type 1 diabetes, too much glucose builds up in the blood because the pancreas is either completely unable to produce insulin or is able to produce only a tiny amount. People with type 1 diabetes must have insulin injections for the rest of their lives. This condition was previously referred to as juvenile-onset diabetes because people are generally younger than 30 years of age when they are diagnosed. However, type 1 diabetes can develop at any age.

data.name: L814
data.value: Type 2 Diabetes – With type 2 diabetes, too much glucose builds up in the blood mainly because the cells become resistant to the insulin the body makes. The pancreas still produces insulin. Insulin levels in the blood may be normal or even too high, but the body doesn’t respond properly to the insulin’s action. People with type 2 diabetes don’t usually take insulin injections. They are more likely to take oral diabetes medications to help keep their blood glucose levels within a normal range. Type 2 diabetes was previously referred to as adult-onset diabetes. People who develop it usually, but not always, are older than 30 when they learn they have it. Type 2 diabetes is far more common than type 1 diabetes. Type 2 diabetes is just as serious a medical condition as type 1 diabetes and should never be taken lightly!

data.name: L815
data.value: If you have diabetes, you can be healthy if you take care of yourself and follow the recommendations of your diabetes care providers. But, if you have diabetes and it is not well controlled, you can get into serious trouble.

data.name: L816
data.value: Some complications occur rather abruptly and can cause a coma, which can be fatal. These are referred to as acute complications. Acute complications usually occur when the blood glucose level rises too high (hyperglycemia) or falls too low (hypoglycemia).

data.name: L817
data.value: Chronic complications do not appear suddenly, but develop over the long term. These can also be fatal. Three major types of chronic problems can arise.

data.name: L818
data.value: Damage to Blood Vessels – Diabetes works together with other heart disease risk factors to damage blood vessels. These damaged blood vessels can cause heart attacks, strokes, poor circulation, kidney failure, and eye problems.

data.name: L819
data.value: Damage to Nerves – Diabetes damages nerves. This damage may cause numbness or pain or it may reduce feeling, especially in the feet and legs. If you are injured and feel no pain because of numbness, the injury may go unnoticed until it worsens considerably. Nerve damage, called neuropathy, may also cause circulation and sexual problems.

data.name: L82
data.value: Despite an adequate number of hours of sleep, I still feel tired or sleepy upon awakening

data.name: L820
data.value: Decreased Ability to Fight Infections – High blood glucose slows the work of the white blood cells that fight infections in the body. Infections can become serious very quickly when the body is not able to fight them off. Skin, dental, urinary, and vaginal infections occur more frequently in people with diabetes.

data.name: L821
data.value: The goal of diabetes management is to avoid the acute and chronic complications of diabetes. You can avoid complications of diabetes by keeping blood glucose levels in the recommended ranges. It is also critical that you take action to control your other heart disease risk factors. Because you have diabetes, your other risk factor goals are more rigorous than for most people without diabetes.

data.name: L822
data.value: Lifestyle management will always be the foundation of your diabetes management plan regardless of medications and other actions prescribed by your diabetes care providers.

data.name: L823
data.value: Because you have diabetes, you will need extra screenings and assessments. These additional tests will be performed by your doctor or other specialists:

data.name: L824
data.value: An A1C test will be done at least two times per year. A1C reflects blood glucose control over the previous two to three months.

data.name: L825
data.value: A fasting blood test to evaluate your blood cholesterol and triglyceride levels will be performed annually or more frequently if needed.

data.name: L826
data.value: Screening for albumin in the urine (an early warning sign of kidney disease) will begin as soon as diabetes is diagnosed.

data.name: L827
data.value: Additional heart-related tests may be performed depending upon your health and risk factor status.

data.name: L828
data.value: In addition to the above screenings and assessments, you should have the following preventive care:

data.name: L829
data.value: Get a flu shot every year.

data.name: L830
data.value: Have a pneumococcal vaccination to reduce your risk for pneumonia.

data.name: L831
data.value: If you have had diabetes for three or more years, were diagnosed with diabetes after age 30, or have visual symptoms or eye problems, have a complete eye exam every year. If eye disease is detected, more frequent examinations may be required.

data.name: L832
data.value: Have your dentist or dental hygienist clean your teeth every six months. Tell your dentist you have diabetes.

data.name: L833
data.value: Have a thorough foot examination at least once a year.

data.name: L834
data.value: Have your blood pressure checked whenever you see your doctor.

data.name: L835
data.value: My Warning Signs to be Aware of – Blood Glucose Emergencies

data.name: L836
data.value: There are two major kinds of blood glucose emergencies:

data.name: L837
data.value: Hypoglycemia – Hypo means low and glycemia means blood glucose level. A dangerously low blood glucose level is the most common problem for people with type 1 diabetes and for those with type 2 who are on insulin therapy or take certain oral diabetes medicines. When your blood glucose is too low you may:

data.name: L84
data.value: I have been told that I have frequent pauses in breathing while sleeping

data.name: L843
data.value: Hyperglycemia – Hyper means high. Untreated hyperglycemia can lead to coma. Early warning symptoms are:

data.name: L848
data.value: Call your diabetes care providers for any of these situations:

data.name: L849
data.value: If your blood glucose is over 240 mg/dl (13.3 mmol/L) and moderate or large amounts of ketones are present in your urine, call your diabetes care providers immediately. If trace or small amounts of ketones are present, you should test your blood glucose and urine ketones every three or four hours. If your blood glucose and ketone numbers are not going down after two tests, call your doctor.

data.name: L85
data.value: I have headaches in the morning

data.name: L850
data.value: If your blood glucose is consistently below your recommended goal range or if you are experiencing problems with hypoglycemia, call your doctor.

data.name: L851
data.value: If you have infections on your skin or feet that do not seem to heal properly, see your doctor immediately.

data.name: L852
data.value: If your blood glucose is 400 mg/dl (22.2 mmol/L) or higher, call your doctor or diabetes care providers immediately, even if ketones are not present in your urine.

data.name: L853
data.value: If you experience any symptoms or signs of heart problems before, during, or after your exercise session, discuss them with your doctor before continuing your exercise program.

data.name: L854
data.value: If you are sick, call your diabetes care providers if you have any problems or symptoms of complications.

data.name: L855
data.value: Diabetes is one of the most common chronic diseases. Diabetes cannot be cured, but it can be prevented and/or controlled.

data.name: L856
data.value: When you eat sugars and starches, the body changes them into a form of sugar called glucose. Glucose enters the blood and is carried to all of the cells of the body where it is ready to be used for energy. The hormone insulin, which is produced in the pancreas, is responsible for moving the glucose out of the blood and into the cells. Too much glucose in the blood is dangerous and can cause damage to organs in the body. People with diabetes have problems regulating the amount of glucose in their blood. When left untreated, they have too much glucose in their blood. Once the amount of glucose in the blood exceeds a certain level, excess glucose spills over into the urine. Diabetes mellitus comes from the Greek word diabetes (to flow through; urine) and the Latin word mellitus (sweetened or honey-like).

data.name: L857
data.value: People with diabetes are at increased risk for three major types of chronic problems:

data.name: L858
data.value: Damage to Blood Vessels – Diabetes works together with other heart disease risk factors to damage blood vessels. These damaged blood vessels can cause heart attacks, strokes, poor circulation, kidney failure, and eye problems.

data.name: L859
data.value: Damage to Nerves – Diabetes damages nerves. This damage may cause numbness or pain or it may reduce feeling, especially in the feet and legs. Nerve damage may also cause circulation and sexual problems.

data.name: L86
data.value: I feel very tired or sleepy during the day

data.name: L860
data.value: Decreased Ability to Fight Infections – High blood glucose slows the work of the white blood cells that fight infections in the body. Skin, dental, urinary, and vaginal infections occur more frequently in people with diabetes.

data.name: L861
data.value: Before people develop type 2 diabetes, most have prediabetes – fasting blood glucose levels that are higher than normal (that is, 100 mg/dl [or 5.6 mmol/L] or higher) but not yet high enough to be diagnosed as diabetes (that is, 126 mg/dl [or 7 mmol/L] or higher). Prediabetes is a serious medical condition that can be prevented and treated.

data.name: L862
data.value: People with prediabetes are at increased risk of developing diabetes in the future. We also now know that prediabetes causes some long-term damage to the body, especially the heart and blood vessels. Prediabetes is a serious medical condition that can be prevented and treated.

data.name: L863
data.value: The good news is that you can delay or prevent type 2 diabetes from ever developing if you manage your blood glucose by:

data.name: L865
data.value: increasing your level of physical activity

data.name: L87
data.value: None of the above apply to me

data.name: L879
data.value: Cancer is a leading cause of death. Although anyone can get cancer at any age, about three-quarters of all cancers are diagnosed in people 55 and older. Today, millions of people are living with cancer or have been cured of the disease.

data.name: L88
data.value: Please indicate the state of your health.

data.name: L880
data.value: There are many kinds of cancer. They all start when abnormal cells in a part of the body begin to grow out of control. These cancer cells may spread by a process called "metastasis" to other parts of the body where they grow and replace normal tissue. Regardless of where a cancer may spread to, it is always named for the place it first began. For example, breast cancer that spreads to the liver is still called breast cancer, not liver cancer. Different types of cancer can act very differently, which is why people with cancer need treatment that is aimed at their specific type of cancer.

data.name: L881
data.value: In many cases, the exact reasons why a person develops cancer is not known. A cancer risk factor is anything that increases your chances of getting cancer. Having one or more cancer risk factors means that you are more likely to develop cancer at some point in your life. However, it does not necessarily mean that you will definitely get cancer.

data.name: L882
data.value: Some cancer risk factors can be changed, and others cannot. Risk factors for cancer include:

data.name: L886
data.value: Cancer-causing factors in the environment, including certain chemicals and radiation (x-rays)

data.name: L888
data.value: Lifestyle factors such as tobacco and alcohol use, diet, physical inactivity, and sun exposure

data.name: L889
data.value: Different types of cancer have different risk factors. Risk factors for some specific kinds of cancer include:

data.name: L890
data.value: Cancers of the lung, mouth, larynx, bladder, kidney, cervix, esophagus, and pancreas - tobacco use, including cigarettes, cigars, chewing tobacco, and snuff. Smoking alone causes one-third of all cancer deaths.

data.name: L891
data.value: Skin cancer - unprotected exposure to strong sunlight.

data.name: L892
data.value: Breast cancer (women) - age; changes in hormone levels throughout life, such as age at first menstruation, number of pregnancies, and age at menopause; obesity; physical inactivity; excessive alcohol consumption; and having a mother or sister who have had breast cancer.

data.name: L893
data.value: Prostate cancer (men) - age (risk increases with age), race (more common among African-American men than among white men), a high-fat diet, and having a father or brother who have had prostate cancer.

data.name: L894
data.value: The risk of developing most types of cancer can be reduced by changes in a person's lifestyle, for example, by:

data.name: L895
data.value: Not using tobacco (cigarettes, cigars, pipes and smokeless tobacco can all cause cancer and should not be used)

data.name: L896
data.value: Eating a healthy diet (eat a lot of fresh fruits, vegetables and whole grains, and cut down on high-fat foods)

data.name: L898
data.value: Using alcohol not at all or only in moderation

data.name: L899
data.value: Staying in the shade as much as you can, wearing a hat and shirt when you are in the sun, and using sunscreen

data.name: L900
data.value: There are special tests, called screening examinations, that adults should have in order to find cancer early. Finding cancer early usually means it can be treated while it is still small and less likely to have spread to other parts of the body. If cancer is found early, it can often be cured. The sooner a cancer is found and the sooner treatment begins, the better a person’s chances are of a cure.

data.name: L901
data.value: A good example of the importance of early cancer detection is melanoma skin cancer. It is a potentially lethal condition once it has spread to other parts of the body. But it can be easily removed if it has not yet grown deeply into the skin and spread to other parts of the body. The 5-year survival rate (percentage of people living at least 5 years after diagnosis) at this stage is nearly 100%.

data.name: L902
data.value: See the cancer screening examinations recommended for you in the printable summary report for your doctor and your action plan.

data.name: L903
data.value: My Warning Signs to be Aware of – Cancer

data.name: L904
data.value: Cancer, as a group of diseases, may cause almost any sign or symptom. The precise signs and symptoms depend on where the cancer is, the size of the cancer, and how much it affects the surrounding body organs. If a cancer metastasizes (or spreads), then symptoms may occur in several different parts of the body at the same time.

data.name: L905
data.value: It is important for you to know what some of the general signs and symptoms of cancer are. According to the American Cancer Society, they include:

data.name: L906
data.value: Unexplained weight loss - an unexplained or unintentional weight loss of 10 pounds or more may be the first sign of cancer, particularly cancers of the pancreas, stomach, esophagus, or lung.

data.name: L907
data.value: Fever - is very common with cancer, but most often occurs in advanced cases (less often, fever may be an early sign of cancer, such as with leukemia or lymphoma).

data.name: L908
data.value: Fatigue - may be a significant symptom as cancer progresses (it may occur early with certain cancers such as with leukemia or if the cancer causes a chronic loss of blood, as in some colon or stomach cancers).

data.name: L909
data.value: Pain - may be an early symptom with some cancers, such as bone cancers or testicular cancer (most often, however, pain is a symptom of advanced cancer).

data.name: L910
data.value: Skin changes - in addition to skin cancer, some internal cancers can produce visible skin signs such as darkening, yellowing, reddening, itching, or excessive hair growth.

data.name: L911
data.value: In addition to the above general symptoms, you should bring the following common symptoms, which could be an indication of cancer, to your doctor’s attention as soon as possible so that they can be investigated:

data.name: L912
data.value: Change in bowel habits or bladder function

data.name: L915
data.value: Thickening or lump in breast or other parts of the body

data.name: L917
data.value: Recent change in a wart or mole

data.name: L919
data.value: Of course, it’s important to remember that having any of these does not necessarily mean that cancer is present - there are many other conditions that can cause these signs and symptoms as well. However, it is best to report them to you doctor as soon as possible. Even if it has nothing to do with cancer, your doctor can investigate your symptoms and provide treatment, if needed. If it is cancer, you will give yourself the best chance to have it treated early and successfully.

data.name: L920
data.value: Be aware that while the signs and symptoms listed above are the more common ones seen with cancer, there are many others that are not listed here.

data.name: L982
data.value: Heart Disease and Stroke Risk Scores

data.name: L984
data.value:
For adults who do not already have heart disease and have not already had a stroke or TIA, depending on their age, it may be possible to calculate a variety of risk scores. These include:

Framingham 10-year CHD risk score. This score tells you your risk (or likelihood) of developing CHD in the next 10 years.

For most ages, it is also possible to determine the Framingham 10-year CHD risk score for a low-risk person – we call this the Desirable Risk. We call the age where the Desirable Risk matches your Framingham 10-year CHD risk score, your Heart Age.

10-year ASCVD risk score. This score tells you your risk (or likelihood) of developing or dying from atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) in the next 10 years. For this score, ASCVD is defined as having a first heart attack or stroke or dying from CHD or stroke.

Lifetime ASCVD risk score. This score tells you the lifetime risk (or likelihood) of developing or dying from ASCVD for a person at age 50 years with your risk factor levels. For this score, ASCVD is defined as having a first heart attack or stroke or dying from CHD or stroke.

data.name: L2401
data.value: Stroke : Brain damage resulting from an interruption of blood flow to the brain. Transient ischemic attack : A brief interruption of blood flow to the brain, usually causing the brain cells to pause in their normal functioning for only a few minutes. The symptoms are the same symptoms as for a full-fledged stroke. Unlike a stroke, however, there is no permanent brain damage. Also called a "TIA" or "mini-stroke" or "a stroke warning spell" (because TIAs often happen before a major stroke).

data.name: L2402
data.value: Heart attack : Irreversible damage to an area of the heart muscle resulting from an interruption of blood flow. Also called "myocardial infarct" or "MI". Coronary artery bypass surgery : A surgical technique by which blood is detoured around a blocked coronary artery with the use of a vein or an artery from another part of the body. Angioplasty (PTCA) : A procedure used to dilate (or widen) the coronary arteries at sites where they have become narrowed by plaque buildup. Also called a "percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty" or "PTCA". Stent : A device that is inserted in a coronary artery during an angioplasty (or PTCA) procedure to help keep the artery open.

data.name: L2403
data.value: Angina : Chest pain or discomfort resulting from an inadequate supply of blood and oxygen to the heart muscle.

data.name: L2404
data.value: Arteries to your legs : Blockages in the arteries to the legs, caused by the buildup of plaque, are referred to as peripheral arterial disease. Symptoms may include pain or lameness in the buttocks or legs. Typically, these symptoms are only felt during exercise and are relieved by rest. Carotid arteries : Carotid artery disease, a major cause of strokes, is caused by the build up of plaque in one or both of the two main arteries in the neck (called the carotid arteries) that supply blood to the brain.

data.name: L2405
data.value: Cholesterol : A fat-like substance that travels through the bloodstream and increases the risk for heart disease. Triglycerides : A type of fat in the blood that increases the risk for heart disease.

data.name: L2406
data.value: Diabetes : A disease caused by problems regulating the amount of glucose or sugar in the blood. There are two main types of diabetes: type 1 and type 2

data.name: L2407
data.value: Polycystic ovarian syndrome : A common hormonal disorder among women of reproductive age that increases the risk of type 2 diabetes and heart disease. Symptoms and signs include infrequent or prolonged menstrual periods, difficulty becoming pregnant, excess hair growth, acne and obesity

data.name: L2408
data.value: Asthma : A chronic disease that inflames and narrows the airways - the tubes that carry air in and out of your lungs. Asthma causes recurring episodes of wheezing (a whistling sound when you breathe), coughing, chest tightness, and trouble breathing, especially at night and in the early morning.

data.name: L2409
data.value: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) :Because a person may have both diseases at the same time, doctors prefer to use the term COPD to describe both conditions. The airways—the tubes that carry air in and out of your lungs—are partly obstructed, making it hard to breathe. COPD does not include asthma.

data.name: L2412
data.value: Chronic bronchitis or emphysema: COPD or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is a term referring to two lung diseases: chronic bronchitis or emphysema. Because a person may have both diseases at the same time, doctors prefer to use the term COPD to describe both conditions. In COPD, the airways—the tubes that carry air in and out of your lungs—are partly obstructed, making it hard to breathe. COPD does not include asthma.

data.name: L2413
data.value: Sleep apnea : A sleep disorder that occurs when the breathing passages collapse or are blocked

data.name: L2414
data.value: Aerobic physical activity : Exercise or activity using large muscles (such as the legs) that can be performed continuously for more than several minutes at a time. Examples include brisk walking, jogging, swimming and cycling.

data.name: L2415
data.value: Sigmoidoscopy : A partial exam of the colon that uses a thin flexible tube with a camera to look for colon cancer.

data.name: L2416
data.value: Osteoporosis : Also called "brittle bone disease." Bones become fragile and more likely to break. This condition is more common in women than in men.

data.name: L2417
data.value: Fasting : Means not eating or drinking anything other than water for at least eight hours.

data.name: L2418
data.value: Your individualized program includes education on important health topics. The topics recommended for you are based on your specific needs and preferences. The key educational modules assigned to you are listed below.

data.name: L2419
data.value: A1C: A blood test performed in people with diabetes. A1C provides a good indication of a person’s average blood glucose (blood sugar) level over the preceding two to three months.

data.name: L2420
data.value: High-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol: "Good" cholesterol that works to remove plaque from the walls of the arteries.

data.name: L2421
data.value: Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol: "Bad" cholesterol that causes atherosclerotic plaque to build up inside the arteries and block the flow of blood.

data.name: L2422
data.value: A type of fat in the blood that increases the risk for heart disease.

data.name: L2423
data.value: Blood glucose : The amount of glucose or "sugar" in the blood.

data.name: L2181
data.value: Using Ratings of Perceived Exertion (RPE) to Monitor Exercise Intensity

data.name: L2185
data.value: One way to monitor how hard you are exercising is to give an overall, at-the-moment rating of how hard the exercise feels to you. This simple, easy method has been used for more than 40 years by doctors and exercise physiologists to help them communicate with their patients. The Ratings of Perceived Exertion (RPE) scale has numbers from 6 to 20, with words describing the odd numbers on the scale. You can use this scale for rating your effort during any type of exercise.

data.name: L2186
data.value: Read the words by the odd numbers and then pick the number that best describes how hard the exercise feels to you.

data.name: L2188
data.value: Don’t rate any one specific aspect of your exercise, such as breathing or tired legs. Focus on your overall feeling of effort.

data.name: L2189
data.value: Be honest in your rating. If you are in doubt, pick the higher number.

data.name: L2191
data.value: How and What You Can Expect to Feel

data.name: L2194
data.value: The exercise feels fairly light or even easier.

data.name: L2195
data.value: You don’t sweat much and your breathing only increases slightly.

data.name: L2196
data.value: It is quite easy for you to keep exercising.

data.name: L2201
data.value: You will definitely sweat and your breathing will be above normal. At most, it is only moderately difficult for you to continue exercising.

data.name: L2203
data.value: The exercise feels more than just somewhat hard.

data.name: L2628
data.value: Welcome to the INTERVENT with OPTIFAST Weight Management Program

data.name: L2630
data.value: INTERVENT/WM with OPTIFAST® is a medically-supervised weight management program that closely monitors and assesses progress toward your desired weight, better health and emotional well-being.

data.name: L2631
data.value: The high-protein, low-caloric meal replacement plan has been successfully used in Canada for more than 20 years to help obese patients obtain a healthier weight and body mass index (BMI).

data.name: L2632
data.value: Can risk factors be improved without taking medications?

data.name: L2633
data.value: In a study published in the American Journal of Cardiology, we demonstrated improvements in blood pressure, LDL (or “bad”) cholesterol level and fasting blood glucose through weight loss and other lifestyle interventions alone in individuals with elevated values. Within only 3 months of starting the INTERVENT program, many participants had already achieved goal levels without taking medications.

data.name: L2634
data.value: Our mission is to optimize the health of as many people as possible by providing them with affordable and cost-effective access to credible, evidence-based lifestyle management and chronic disease risk reduction services. INTERVENT has more than 100 publications in peer-reviewed medical journals that attest to the many benefits that participants derive – including long-term weight loss in conjunction with a reduction in the risk for heart disease, stroke, diabetes and other chronic conditions.

data.name: L2635
data.value: The Booster Phase typically lasts between 8 and 12 weeks, depending upon your initial weight and weight loss goal. During this time, weight loss is typically most rapid. If you follow the plan outlined for the OPTIFAST Booster Phase, you should lose 1 to 2 kilograms (about 2 to 4½ pounds) per week.

data.name: L2636
data.value: During the Transition Phase, you reduce the OPTIFAST meal replacements as you add new foods to your meal plans. After about 6 weeks in the Transition Phase, you should be eating only regular foods without gaining weight or while continuing to slowly lose weight. The key to weight management is not to let 1 kilogram gained turn into 2, 5 or 10 kilograms or more (5 to 25 pounds) gained in the short term.

data.name: L2637
data.value: After you have completed the Booster and Transition Phases, you are encouraged to continue participating in the comprehensive lifestyle management program from INTERVENT. Research shows that people who stay involved in a behavior modification program beyond their initial weight loss are the most successful in keeping weight off for good.

data.name: L2638
data.value: Of course, you can always use OPTIFAST meal replacements for continued weight loss, to stay on track or as a convenient fast and healthy snack.

data.name: L2639
data.value: Our engaging and easy-to-use digital health platform, modules, audios, recipes, tools and devices address comprehensive health and lifestyle topics – nutrition and weight management, physical activity and stress management.

data.name: L2640
data.value: Your personal health coach will help you choose topics from INTERVENT’s 100+ interactive educational modules. Each module includes a 1 to 2 page summary of key concepts to assist in your weight loss efforts. Brief audios are also provided for you to use for review and reinforcement.

data.value: You are not alone. You are supported by a team of health professionals with expertise in weight management, including a doctor, dietician and professional health coach - both face-to-face and via the telephone

data.name: L2642
data.value: We go beyond weight loss to weight management. Follow our method to keep your weight within 1 to 2 kilograms (2 to 5 pounds) of your goal for the rest of your life.

data.name: L2676
data.value: Complete Your First Health Coaching Session

data.name: L2683
data.value: The health assessment is a free confidential online assessment that considers your lifestyle habits and health history to determine how healthy you are and whether you’re at risk for certain chronic diseases or illnesses. It only takes about 15 minutes to complete.

data.name: L2684
data.value: Our caring, dedicated health coaches are available to help you make the lifestyle changes that are important to you at this time. Points are awarded when you enroll in the lifestyle health coaching program and complete your first session with your coach.

data.name: L2685
data.value:
Keeping your regularly scheduled appointments with your health coach is important to your success in making and sustaining lifestyle changes. Your coach will listen to your needs, preferences and circumstances and help you stay on track to achieve your goals. He or she will be there to support you every step of the way to better health.

    What's Required
  • The number of coaching sessions that you may receive during a program year depends upon your responses to the HRA and other factors. While you should aim to complete all coaching sessions for maximum benefit, you must complete about 75 percent of your sessions to earn this incentive.
  • Ask your health coach to tell you the specific number of sessions you must complete and the deadline for completing your sessions.

data.name: L2686
data.value: Your HRA will be more accurate and complete if you know your health numbers – your blood pressure, fasting blood values, body weight and height. Knowing your numbers is an important step in understanding how to make smart decisions about your health. You can obtain your health numbers from your personal health care provider or from a local lab. Print the “Know Your Numbers” form from "My Program," fill in the numbers and provide the appropriate signature. Next, enter your health numbers into the Health Measurements section of your health assessment or provide them to your coach.

data.name: L2691
data.value: Welcome to Full Circle Health Coaching Lifestyle Management Program

data.name: L2692
data.value: "A woman is the full circle. Within her is the power to create, nurture and transform." - Diane Mariechild

data.name: L2693
data.value: Your Journey to Optimal Health and Well-Being Starts Here... and Now

data.name: L2694
data.value: Welcome to Full Circle Health Coaching LLC Online Portal

data.name: L2695
data.value: Full Circle Health Coaching LLC is a wellness solution specializing in chronic disease prevention and health promotion in women of color. As a licensed network professional of INTERVENT, Full Circle offers evidence-based lifestyle management programs that will empower you to achieve your optimal health and well-being. Take the first step to optimize your health by creating your account, signing up and completing your health assessment.

data.name: L2696
data.value: You must first complete an assessment before enrolling in a lifestyle management program. You may call us at (404) 537-3719 if you have any questions or would like to enroll over the phone.

data.name: L2698
data.value: Our mission is to guide you on your journey to optimal health and well-being using a plant-based approach. Scientific studies suggest positive relationships between a vegetarian meal plan and reduced risk for several chronic diseases and conditions, including coronary heart disease, stroke, obesity, hypertension, diabetes and some types of cancer. Your professional health coach will support you every step of the way on your path to better health for life.

data.name: L2700
data.value: Welcome to Full Circle Health Coaching LLC

data.name: L2701
data.value: Attend a Free Plant-Based Nutrition Education Webinar

data.name: L2702
data.value: CardioSmart is a patient-centered initiative of the prestigious American College of Cardiology. INTERVENT is part of this unique program that encourages patients to play a more active and informed role in their own heart health. Here’s how to access these valuable resources:

data.name: L2706
data.value: At INTERVENT, it is our goal to provide outstanding service at every point of interaction between our staff and participants in our lifestyle health coaching program. Knowing your opinion related to various aspects of the coaching program helps us determine needs and set priorities for improving the program and participant experience. After reviewing your follow-up progress report you will be asked to complete a brief survey regarding your program experience.

data.name: L2707
data.value:
Follow-up evaluations are important to you and to INTERVENT. Nothing motivates like success. Your follow-up survey is scheduled after about 12 weeks of participation in the coaching program. The follow-up questionnaire is similar to the HRA questionnaire that you completed at the beginning of your program – only shorter.

After completing your follow-up evaluation, you will receive a progress report that compares your baseline health numbers to your current values. Your report will also outline the topics that you have covered during your coaching sessions.

data.name: L2709
data.value: Learn how your lifestyle habits measure up to others like you. And, if you are enrolled in an eligible Crothall Healthcare medical plan, you will receive a $3 per week wellness reward for completing your health assessment, which could amount to $156 over the year. This reward is also available to spouses.

data.name: L2711
data.value:
Associates and spouses covered by an eligible medical plan who are expecting a baby may earn a Walmart gift card if the mother completes the INTERVENT maternity lifestyle management program.
-$250 Walmart gift card if enrolled during weeks one to 13
-$125 Walmart gift card if enrolled during weeks 14 to 26
-$0 if enrolled during weeks 27 to 40 or later

The free coaching program includes up to 12 telephonic coaching sessions with a dedicated lifestyle health coach over the course of the program year. Prenatal topics include general topics to support the pregnancy. Post-partum topics include physical activity, weight management, nutrition, stress management, risk factor reduction and general prevention. INTERVENT provides a free copy of the Mayo Clinic Guide to a Healthy Pregnancy. The website www.text4baby.com is also recommended for pregnancy resources and parenting resources through the baby’s first year. Women are reminded to keep all appointments with their health care provider and to access resources from the local health system where their baby will be delivered.

The Walmart gift card will be delivered in the month following completion of the maternity lifestyle management program.

data.name: L2713
data.value:
Tobacco use is a major modifiable risk factor for cardiovascular disease, lung and other cancers and other serious conditions. It’s also very difficult to break the habit and stay tobacco free. Compass Group and INTERVENT offer several resources to help tobacco users assess their readiness to quit and get started on the path to becoming tobacco free for good.

  • Orientation/Getting started with tobacco cessation – An online video is provided for tobacco users to help them evaluate their readiness to give up tobacco and identify resources and support to help them quit.
  • Comprehensive telephonic lifestyle health coaching program – Tobacco users may enroll for up to 12 individual sessions with a dedicated health coach over the program year. Upon enrollment, coaches help participants develop a plan to quit in about 30 days (or more if needed). Coupled with the coaching program, the availability of free nicotine replacement therapy (mailed to the home) from Compass Group also enhances the success rate for smokers who have a strong addiction to nicotine.

At least 12 weeks of compliance with the INTERVENT comprehensive lifestyle health coaching program (with a future appointment scheduled) will remove the Compass Group tobacco use surcharge which is $24 per week that could amount to $1,248 over the year. Compliance is defined as being enrolled in the coaching program for at least 12 weeks, completing a minimum of four telephone coaching sessions and having a subsequent appointment scheduled.

data.name: L2715
data.value: The health risk assessment (HRA) is a free confidential online assessment that considers your lifestyle habits and health history to determine how healthy you are and whether you’re at risk for certain chronic diseases or illnesses. It only takes about 15 minutes to complete.

data.name: L2717
data.value:
Your lifestyle health coach knows your needs and understands your goals for benefitting your health. As you work together, your coach may award bonus points for your outstanding efforts and accomplishments.

What's Required

Here are some of the ways you might earn these special rewards from your coach:

  • Read and complete your online educational Kits and quiz
  • Sync an electronic device to your program and share the results with your coach
  • Complete diaries or logs regularly
  • Report your personal data – weight, blood pressure and minutes of physical activity – at each call
  • Set an action goal and work to achieve it
  • Any other outstanding effort or accomplishment

data.name: L2719
data.value: You can earn an additional $2 per week credit by completing a brief telephone “Next Step” navigation call with INTERVENT. During this call, you will review your HRA results and learn about the wellness programs available through Compass Group. Plus, you can learn more about whether you would benefit from having a personal lifestyle coach. If you are not enrolled in the INTERVENT telephonic health coaching program, you may email us at info@myintervent.com to complete your navigation call immediately or to schedule a time for the navigation call that is convenient for you.

data.name: L2721
data.value:
Your primary care physician is in charge of your overall health care. In addition to providing treatment if you should become sick with a temporary illness, your primary care physician is in charge of your preventive care and immunizations. He or she can also help manage any chronic conditions you may have or refer you to a specialist, if needed. Be sure to plan to have an annual wellness exam with your primary care physician.

What's Required

  • Provide the full name and city for your primary care physician. (INTERVENT will never contact your primary care physician without your permission.)
  • If you don’t currently have a primary care physician, your health coach can help you find one in your area who is on your medical plan.

data.name: L2724
data.value:
Keeping your regularly scheduled appointments with your health coach is important to your success in making and sustaining lifestyle changes. Your coach will listen to your needs, preferences and circumstances and help you stay on track to achieve your goals. He or she will be there to support you every step of the way to better health.

What's Required

  • The number of coaching sessions that you may receive during a program year depends upon your responses to the health assessment and other factors. While you should aim to complete all coaching sessions for maximum benefit, you must complete about 75 percent of your sessions to earn this incentive.
  • Ask your health coach to tell you the specific number of sessions you must complete and the deadline for completing your sessions.

data.name: L2733
data.value: INTERVENT/WM with OPTIFAST is a medically-supervised weight management program that closely monitors and assesses progress toward your desired weight, better health and emotional well-being. The program uses a phased approach:

data.name: L2734
data.value: Booster Phase (8 to 12 weeks) – Take up to 3 OPTIFAST meal replacements per day along with a dinner meal of lean protein and non-starchy vegetables. Weight loss is typically most rapid during this phase.

data.name: L2735
data.value: Transition Phase (about 6 weeks) – Add new foods to your daily meal plan while reducing the use of OPTIFAST meals. You may continue to lose weight or avoid gaining weight.

data.name: L2736
data.value: Management Phase (ongoing) – Follow our comprehensive weight management program designed to keep weight off and promote optimal health and well-being.

data.name: L2737
data.value: You will receive an action plan, as well as educational modules on many topics related to weight loss and weight management. Throughout the entire program, you will be supported by a team of health professionals with expertise in weight management, including a doctor, dietician and professional health coach –both in face-to-face sessions and via the telephone/Internet.

data.value:
Associates and spouses covered by an eligible medical plan who are expecting a baby may earn an Amazon gift card if the mother completes the INTERVENT maternity lifestyle management program.

-$500 Amazon gift card if enrolled during weeks one to 13
-$250 Amazon gift card if enrolled during weeks 14 to 26
-$100 Amazon gift card if enrolled during weeks 27 to 40 or later

The free coaching program includes up to 12 telephonic coaching sessions with a dedicated lifestyle health coach over the course of the program year. Prenatal topics include general topics to support the pregnancy. Post-partum topics include physical activity, weight management, nutrition, stress management, risk factor reduction and general prevention. INTERVENT provides a free copy of the Mayo Clinic Guide to a Healthy Pregnancy. The website www.text4baby.com is also recommended for pregnancy resources and parenting resources through the baby’s first year. Women are reminded to keep all appointments with their health care provider and to access resources from the local health system where their baby will be delivered.

The Amazon gift card will be delivered by email in the month following completion of the maternity lifestyle management program.

data.value: Your HRA will be more accurate and complete if you know your health numbers – your blood pressure, fasting blood values, body weight and height. Knowing your numbers is an important step in understanding how to make smart decisions about your health. You can obtain your health numbers from your personal health care provider or from a local lab. Select an option from “My Labs,” and receive an additional $2 per week wellness credit for submitting your results if you are on an eligible Compass Group medical plan.

data.name: L2838
data.value: You can earn an additional $3 per week credit by completing a brief telephone “coaching results” call with INTERVENT. During this call, you will review your lab results and HRA. Plus, you can learn more about whether you would benefit from having a personal lifestyle coach. If you are not enrolled in the INTERVENT telephonic health coaching program, you may email us at info@myintervent.com to complete your review call immediately or to schedule a time for the review call that is convenient for you.

data.name: L2856
data.value: Step 2: Submit a copy of your blood pressure and blood test results from your personal doctor to INTERVENT or obtain a free blood pressure and lab test from a local LabCorp facility for an additional $2 in weekly wellness credits*. Test results obtained in the past 365 days count toward your 2019 credit. Information about the required tests and how to provide these results is provided at the end of the HRA. Required blood tests include total cholesterol, triglycerides, LDL (“bad”) cholesterol, HDL (“good”) cholesterol and glucose or A1C. Fasting blood test results are preferred but not mandatory.

data.name: L2857
data.value: Step 3: Participate in a Coaching Results call to review your lab test results with INTERVENT for an additional $3 weekly wellness credit*. INTERVENT can also help you find a primary care doctor if you don’t currently have one and make referrals to other wellness resources as appropriate. If you enroll in the 2019 INTERVENT lifestyle health coaching program, this session counts as your first coaching appointment.

Only participants enrolled and actively participating in the lifestyle health coaching program are eligible for the drawings.

Our loyal participants who met the required number of coaching sessions for 2018 will get a “jumpstart” key at the beginning of the 2019 program year.

data.name: L2866
data.value: If a recent fasting blood glucose test or A1C test has indicated that you have prediabetes, INTERVENT can help. Prediabetes means that your blood glucose (sugar) values are higher than normal but are not yet high enough for a diagnosis of diabetes. People with prediabetes are at high risk for type 2 diabetes (the most common type of diabetes), heart disease and stroke.

data.name: L2867
data.value: A special diabetes prevention version of the INTERVENT telephonic coaching program is available free of charge to Compass Group associates and spouses with prediabetes on eligible medical plans. Live group educational webinars are included as an option for additional support.

data.name: L2868
data.value: People with prediabetes may also enroll in an online, self-paced INTERVENT diabetes prevention program. The INTERVENT program is proven to work. It’s safe and follows guidelines established by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

data.value: Your physical activity summary index (PA-I) is {0}. Your PA-I places you in the {1} category.

data.name: L3101
data.value: For the following questions, exercise means aerobic physical activity such as walking, jogging, cycling, swimming, fitness classes, sport, etc.

data.name: L3102
data.value: The physical activity summary index (PA-I) is calculated from your self-reported frequency (that is, how often you exercise), intensity (that is, how hard you exercise) and duration (that is, how long you exercise for) of exercise. PA-I scores range from 0 to 15. Higher PA-I scores are associated with a lower risk for developing and dying from heart disease and certain other chronic diseases.

data.name: L3103
data.value: PA-I scores of 1.5 or less place you in the low physical activity category and are associated with a higher risk for developing and dying from heart disease and certain other chronic diseases.

data.name: L3104
data.value: PA-I scores of 1.51 to 3.75 place you in the medium physical activity category and are associated with a lower risk for developing and dying from heart disease and certain other chronic diseases

data.name: L3105
data.value: PA-I scores above 3.75 place you in the high physical activity category and are associated with the lowest risk for developing and dying from heart disease and certain other chronic diseases

data.name: L3117
data.value: Read one of our many success stories

data.name: L3118
data.value: You can win valuable prizes from INTERVENT. INTERVENT provides points for completing various program activities and holds monthly, quarterly, semi-annual and annual drawings to select winners. The more points you earn, the more chances you have to win. Only participants enrolled and actively participating in the health coaching programs are eligible for drawings.

data.name: L3119
data.value: Look for announcements of winners and read stories about how working with an INTERVENT health coach is helping participants move forward on the pathway to optimal health.

data.name: L3120
data.value: The health assessment is a free, confidential online assessment that considers your lifestyle habits and health history to determine how healthy you are and whether you’re at risk for or could better manage certain chronic diseases or illnesses. It only takes about 15 minutes to complete.

data.name: L3121
data.value: Once you complete the health assessment, you will immediately receive a personal wellness report and a wealth of useful information individually tailored for you. You must complete a health assessment before enrolling in a lifestyle health coaching program. Email or call us if you have questions.

data.name: L3122
data.value: Our caring, dedicated health coaches are available at times that are convenient for you. They’ve worked with thousands of participants just like you. Our coaches listen to your needs, preferences and circumstances and help you develop a plan that is individualized for you. Your coach will hold you accountable for the goals that you set for yourself and support you every step of the way to better health.

data.name: L3123
data.value: You must complete a health assessment before enrolling in a lifestyle health coaching program.

data.name: L3124
data.value: Our telephonic health coaching programs include:

data.name: L3125
data.value: Lifestyle management – eating healthfully, being physically active, managing stress, not smoking and following your treatment plan and guidelines for preventive care – is the foundation of optimal health and well-being

data.name: L3126
data.value: If you’re living with a chronic condition, our telephonic health coaching program can help you implement the treatment plan recommended by your doctor or health care provider and live better with your condition.

data.name: L3127
data.value: If you’re generally healthy and want to stay that way, your coaching program will focus on promoting health and wellness, managing risk factors and preventing diseases.

data.name: L3128
data.value: All wellness and chronic medical condition management programs are individualized to meet your needs and preferences. You will take regular small steps that can make a big difference in your health and lifestyle.

data.name: L3129
data.value: When I enrolled in coaching, I learned that I could reduce the risk of my prediabetes turning into type 2 diabetes by losing five to 10 percent of my weight and by being more physically active. With the help of my health coach, I’ve now lost 12 kilos (about 26 pounds) and I’m happy to say that I no longer have prediabetes. My cholesterol values are also in the normal range. I feel great. I couldn’t have made these changes without the support of my health coach. I rate the coaching program as excellent and I definitely recommend it to others who need to deal with a chronic medical condition or who just want to stay healthy.

data.name: L3130
data.value: Not all stress is bad, but even good stress, such as getting a promotion at work, can be stressful and negatively impact your health. Our stress management programs address relaxation and coping skills and other important behaviors that promote resiliency in difficult times. Topics include time management, work/life balance, values, communication styles, confidence building, social support, mindfulness, thinking differently, problem solving, dealing with depression and preventing setbacks. Almost anyone can benefit from our comprehensive, yet individualized, approach to well-being, stress management and resiliency.

data.name: L3131
data.value: For participants who are experiencing issues that are beyond the scope of our coaching program, we’ll make referrals to other appropriate mental health resources.

data.name: L3132
data.value: Everybody experiences stress at some time -- right? Well, for me, my stress was due to the loss of my husband of 25 years. I had been in the well-being coaching program for several months when he died suddenly. Fortunately, I was able to apply many of the principles of resiliency that I had learned from my coach to deal with my grief and stress. I was able to ask for and accept help and seek out others who would listen. I also got involved in some volunteer activities in my community, which helped me focus on others instead of myself. I’m grateful for my coaching experience. This program has something for everyone.

data.name: L3133
data.value: Lifestyle management doesn’t stop when you have an accident, hospitalization, major illness or other setback. In fact, practicing healthier habits during these interruptions in life can help you get back to your normal schedule and to work and pleasurable activities as soon as practically possible.

data.name: L3134
data.value: We’ll help you be your own health advocate to manage a short-term or long-term disability. Your lifestyle health coach can help you access the full spectrum of recovery resources, including outpatient rehabilitation and physical therapy. At the appropriate time, you can transition to our comprehensive lifestyle management program for continued support.

data.name: L3135
data.value: After my back surgery, I was concerned about returning to work, so I enrolled in coaching while I was in physical rehabilitation. During this time, my coach helped me access the various recovery services that were essential for me to return to work. We also focused on weight loss and blood pressure management, both of which were problems before my surgery. After only four weeks, I was able to return to limited duty and after three months I returned to full duty. Now I’ve lost nine kilos (about 20 pounds), my blood pressure has improved and I’m staying active. My risk for future back problems is significantly reduced and I’m enjoying playing golf again. I feel great. I plan to continue to participate in the coaching program.

data.name: L3136
data.value: This lifestyle health coaching program is for women who are pregnant or planning to become pregnant in the near future. Prenatal topics focus primarily on general wellness (nutrition, physical activity, stress management) to support a health pregnancy. Postpartum topics address getting back in shape, losing weight that was gained during pregnancy and adjusting to life with a new baby. A special educational series is available for women who are considering breastfeeding their baby.

data.name: L3137
data.value: Participating in our maternity lifestyle health coaching program can improve the likelihood of a successful pregnancy and healthy baby. Clinical issues are always referred to the woman’s personal doctors or health care providers. Women are also encouraged to make use of prenatal, maternity and newborn care resources provided by the health care providers where they will deliver their baby.

data.name: L3138
data.value: As soon as I knew I was pregnant, I enrolled in the maternity lifestyle coaching program. I didn’t know anything about what it would be like to have a baby, especially the prenatal appointments and tests. My coach answered all my questions and helped me know what to expect at each month along the way. After the birth of my daughter, I continued in the coaching program to lose the extra five kilos (about 11 pounds) I gained during my pregnancy and to get in better shape. After only three months, I’m back at my pre-pregnancy weight. I look forward to my coaching sessions for continued support.

Plus, you’ll be able to take advantage of our lifestyle management programs where you can learn about how to eat more healthfully, manage your weight, reduce your stress level and much more.

data.value: Become empowered to lead a healthier life and reduce your risk of developing type 2 diabetes. data.name: L3231
data.value: When I enrolled in coaching, I learned that I could reduce the risk of my prediabetes turning into type 2 diabetes by losing five to 10 percent of my weight and by being more physically active. With the help of my health coach, I’ve now lost 12 kilos (about 26 pounds) and I’m happy to say that I no longer have prediabetes. My cholesterol values are also in the normal range. I feel great. I couldn’t have made these changes without the support of my health coach. I rate the coaching program as excellent and I definitely recommend it to others who need to deal with a chronic medical condition or who just want to stay healthy.

data.name: L3232
data.value: I have lost 10 kilos (about 22 pounds) with the help of my coach. As a result, my blood pressure and glucose level are within the normal range. My coach is always upbeat and positive. I got a 'high five' at my doctor’s office today! I love my coach and this program.

data.name: L3236
data.value: You Can Achieve A Healthier Tomorrow

data.name: L3239
data.value: What is the Canadian Diabetes Prevention Program?

data.name: L3240
data.value: The Canadian Diabetes Prevention Program (CDPP) is a clinical study that aims to prevent or delay the start of type 2 diabetes in Canadians. The risk of type 2 diabetes is increasing among Canadians and the disease puts a major burden on individuals and the health care system.

data.name: L3241
data.value: For Canadians, the CDPP is modeled, in part, after a similar program developed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in the United States. The U.S. program was based on a landmark study showing that people at risk for type 2 diabetes who take part in a structured lifestyle management program can cut their future risk for developing type 2 diabetes by 58 percent (71 percent for people over 60 years old).

data.name: L3242
data.value: The Canadian study plans to enroll 3,850 adults across all areas of Canada over the next four years. Specifically, this program will test if individualized one-on-one lifestyle health coaching provided via the telephone along with online educational resources are effective in reducing the risk of type 2 diabetes in Canadians.

data.name: L3244
data.value: Clinical studies are a way to learn about and develop new or improved treatments and medications for diseases and conditions. This study will examine behavioral interventions to prevent type 2 diabetes – no medications or changes to your existing medications will be introduced as part of this study. In Canada, there are strict rules and guidelines for designing and conducting clinical studies and Health Canada monitors them very closely.

data.name: L3245
data.value: What companies are involved in this program?

data.name: L3246
data.value: A partnership between highly respected public and private organizations has been created to design, implement, manage and evaluate this program. Participating organizations include:

data.name: L3251
data.value: Who is eligible to participate in the study?

data.name: L3252
data.value: All participants must complete a screening to determine their eligibility. There are two groups of people who are eligible for this program:

data.name: L3253
data.value: Those age 18 to 74 who are deemed at higher risk for developing type 2 diabetes by scoring 33 or above on the CanRisk* questionnaire

data.name: L3254
data.value: Those who have been diagnosed with prediabetes (i.e. A1C value of 6.0 to 6.4 percent (A1C is a measure of your average three-month blood sugar level) and/or fasting blood sugar of 6.1 to 6.9 mmol/L)

data.name: L3255
data.value: Participants must have access to phone and internet via their home, work, friend’s home, relative’s home, public library, or other location.

data.name: L3256
data.value: People who have already been diagnosed with diabetes are not eligible to participate in this program. There are also additional criteria that could exclude someone from participating, such as pregnancy or certain other conditions.

data.name: L3257
data.value: *Anyone age 18 to 74 years is welcome to take the test to find out his or her risk of developing type 2 diabetes. To take the test and find out your risk score,

data.name: L3260
data.value: It is being offered to particpants in major cities across the country (listed here) and Winnipeg and will be expanding to more locations across the country soon.

data.name: L3261
data.value: What must I do if I choose to participate?

data.name: L3262
data.value: If you enroll in the study, you will follow a structured program of healthy eating and physical activity for a period of about one year. There are no clinical treatments or medications being tested as part of the program; it is purely a lifestyle intervention. Except for measurements (weight, waist measurement and blood test) at the beginning, after six months and at the end of the program (you may also be asked to complete these measures half way though the program), no other physical exams or tests are required as part of the program. You will continue to take your usual medications as directed by your health care provider.

data.name: L3263
data.value: During the one-year program, you will work one-on-one with a professional health coach to make lifestyle changes to improve your health and reduce your risk of developing type 2 diabetes. Up to 22 private and confidential coaching sessions will be conducted over the phone at times that are convenient for you (daytime and evening appointments are available). A major advantage of this program is that you don’t have to travel to a clinic to participate in the coaching sessions. You should be able to use a computer or smartphone to access your program materials and tools via the Internet.

data.name: L3264
data.value: Because the program is part of a clinical study, you will be required to complete baseline and follow-up assessments, including several questionnaires and measurements, so that the program’s effectiveness can be evaluated. More information about the specific assessments will be provided before you agree to participate. By taking the time to complete all of the assessments, you will gain useful information while making an important scientific contribution to Canadian health care.

data.name: L3265
data.value: Is my personal health information secure and confidential?

data.name: L3266
data.value: Yes. In Canada, health information must be secured and held confidential by law . For more information about those requirements, click here

data.name: L3267
data.value: What are my rights if I choose to participate in this program?

data.name: L3268
data.value: Your participation in the program is completely voluntary. You will review and accept a privacy policy, service agreement and informed consent before beginning the program. Should you have any concerns about the program or what you are asked to do, please speak to your health coach, an LMC manager at prevention@lmc.ca or the Research Ethics Board, which can be contacted by phone at 1-866-449-8591 or by email at subjectinquiries@irbservices.com.

data.name: L3269
data.value: Is there a cost to participate in the program?

data.name: L3270
data.value: No. The program, including measurements and assessments, is at no cost to you. You will never be asked for credit card or payment information.

data.name: L3271
data.value: Tell me more about the coaching program.

data.name: L3272
data.value: CDPP is a personalized, lifestyle management program that empowers you to lead a healthier life and may reduce your risk for type 2 diabetes. Your personal health coach will guide and support you through this program in a step-by-step manner. Together with your coach, you will set action goals, develop plans and actively engage in trying new healthy habits that are tailored to your needs, interests and personal circumstances. Between coaching sessions, you will be provided with online educational materials to complete and apply to your everyday life. Your health coach will help you be accountable for achieving the goals that are set. You will report your current weight, waist measurement and minutes of aerobic physical activity in the past week.

data.name: L3273
data.value: During the first three months of the program, you’ll meet with your health coach weekly. During months 4 through 12, you’ll have monthly coaching sessions. All coaching calls are via telephone appointments. You should keep all of your coaching appointments. During your first two sessions with your personal health coach, you will get to know each other, review the results of your baseline assessments and establish your personal wellness vision. These sessions are longer than other sessions and will require approximately 30 minutes. Other sessions will require 15 minutes.

data.name: L3274
data.value: The program gives you access to the following, all at no charge:

data.name: L3275
data.value: Twenty-two (22) private telephone sessions with a personal health coach at times that are convenient for you

data.name: L3276
data.value: Access to various health and wellness resources via the online program platform:

data.name: L3277
data.value: Educational modules covering healthy eating, physical activity, weight management, stress management and smoking cessation, if needed

data.name: L3278
data.value: Audio versions of the education modules

data.name: L3280
data.value: Tools to track your eating, exercise and stress

data.name: L3282
data.value: Fun challenges and incentives, including drawings for prizes

data.name: L3283
data.value: Monthly webinars on topics to support and expand upon what you learn in your coaching sessions

data.name: L3284
data.value: Must I go to a gym?

data.name: L3285
data.value: No, you don’t have to go to a gym. You will work with your personal health coach to develop and implement a personal exercise plan that is safe and effective and that suits your needs and preferences. The only thing you’ll need is a good pair of shoes for physical activity.

data.name: L3286
data.value: What are the qualifications of the health coaches?

data.name: L3287
data.value: CDPP health coaches are specially trained health care professionals who have completed a minimum of a university degree in science. The CDPP health coaches may also include certified diabetes educators (CDEs) and registered dietitians (RDs). All CDPP health coaches have experience in helping people make lifestyle changes, especially in the areas of healthy eating and exercise. In addition to their university education, CDPP health coaches have completed at least 100 hours of training specific to this program and health coaching principles.

data.name: L3288
data.value: What results should I expect to achieve?

data.name: L3289
data.value: While results will vary from participant to participant, if you follow the program guidelines, you may experience the following improvements in your lifestyle and health:

data.name: L3290
data.value: Loss of at least five percent of initial weight, if you are overweight

data.name: L3291
data.value: Reduced waist circumference, if you tend to store excess fat in your abdomen

data.name: L3292
data.value: Reduced or maintained blood sugar levels into a normal range

data.name: L3293
data.value: Participation in a minimum of 150 minutes per week of moderate- to vigorous-intensity aerobic physical activity

data.name: L3294
data.value: Ability to follow a meal plan that provides nutrients for good health and energy for maintaining a healthy weight

data.name: L3295
data.value: Increased knowledge about healthy living habits

data.name: L3296
data.value: The overall goal of the program is to help prevent or delay the onset of type 2 diabetes by helping you to develop and practice sustainable healthy habits. In addition to reducing your risk for type 2 diabetes, practicing the lifestyle habits that you learn in this program may reduce your risk for other chronic diseases, including heart disease, stroke and some types of cancer, and improve your overall well-being.

data.name: L3298
data.value: If you were referred to this program by your doctor, you still must go through the appropriate screening steps to confirm your eligibility.

data.name: L3300
data.value: First, determine your eligibility by completing the General Assessment questionnaire,

data.name: L3301
data.value: If you are eligible for the program, you will be directed to the CDPP portal.

data.name: L3302
data.value: You’ll accept an online service agreement, create a CDPP portal account, and then complete an online health assessment.

data.name: L3303
data.value: “Preparing for the CDPP” explains the online baseline assessments and consent forms that you’ll need to complete before beginning your coaching program. These assessments will help your health coach individualize your program.

data.name: L3304
data.value: The “Welcome” module describes the coaching process in more detail and provides information about how people make important changes in their lifestyle. You’ll begin to think about a new level of wellness that you can achieve in the future.

data.name: L3305
data.value:
In addition to completing your online assessments, you will obtain baseline measurements: weight, height, waist measurement and a blood test to determine your A1C and fasting blood sugar.
These measurements will be collected via one of two methods using a physical measurement protocol.

data.name: L3306
data.value: If you need assistance in completing the baseline assessments, you may call {0} to schedule an appointment with a customer care representative who will answer your questions and help you get started.

data.name: L3307
data.value: Important: You will have four weeks to complete the baseline questionnaires and measurements. If you do not complete all of the baseline assessments, including measurements, in the four-week period, you will not be able to continue in the program until you do.

data.name: L3309
data.value: Yes. After six months, your weight and waist measurements and blood test will be repeated at your home. Everyone will complete a brief online follow-up evaluation similar to the health assessment that you completed at baseline. A follow-up progress report will be provided. You also will be invited to complete a survey to assess your satisfaction with the program.

data.name: L3310
data.value: After about 12 months in the program, you will be asked to repeat the online baseline questionnaires and a follow-up evaluation and measurements, including a blood test at your home. You will also meet with your coach one final time for about 45 minutes to review your overall progress in the program and set personal goals for continuing your healthy lifestyle habits in the future. You will be invited to complete another survey to assess your satisfaction with the program. You may also be contacted by phone for 30 minutes to be asked specific questions about your experience in the program. Answering the telephone survey questions is completely voluntary.

data.name: L3311
data.value: A group of 452 participants will be asked to do an additional follow-up evaluation six months after completing their program (18 months after baseline). If you are selected as part of this group, you will repeat the measurements at your home.

data.name: L3312
data.value: What if I’m at risk for type 2 diabetes but I choose not to participate in this program? Are there other resources available?

data.name: L3313
data.value: If you have prediabetes or are at higher risk for type 2 diabetes, visit your health care provider and ask him or her about steps you can take to reduce your risk. Be sure you know the symptoms of type 2 diabetes and plan to have your blood sugar measured every six to 12 months. Many people with risk factors, especially those with prediabetes, go on to develop type 2 diabetes in the future. Type 2 diabetes is just as serious as type 1 diabetes and should not be taken lightly. Unlike type 1 diabetes, however, type 2 diabetes can often be prevented, so take steps today to reduce your risk. Resources are also available from Diabetes Canada and INTERVENT.

data.name: L3317
data.value: CDPP is managed by LMC Healthcare, Canada's largest specialist provider in diabetes and endocrinology. The LMC diabetes education team is comprised of certified diabetes educators (CDEs) with over 15 years of experience. The LMC team has the knowledge, resources and expertise to help improve the health of those living with or at risk of developing type 2 diabetes across the country.

data.name: L3319
data.value: Founded in 1997, INTERVENT is a physician-led global health management company that is dedicated to optimizing the health of as many people as possible by offering affordable and cost-effective access to credible, evidence-based lifestyle management programs and chronic disease risk reduction services.

data.name: L3320
data.value: LMC selected INTERVENT as its main CDPP partner because INTERVENT programs have been proven effective in numerous published studies, including randomized and independently-conducted clinical trials. More than two million individuals have participated in INTERVENT programs, including patients from over 120 medical centers in the United States and Canada as part of two recent multi-center clinical trials funded by the National Institutes of Health.

data.name: L3321
data.value: Why should I recommend the program to my patients with prediabetes?

data.name: L3322
data.value: The LMC Canadian Diabetes Prevention Program (CDPP) has been designed to help participants reduce their risk factors for developing type 2 diabetes. This no cost, evidence-based program offers individualized telephonic health coaching and goal setting, online learning modules and live group learning sessions to help your patients achieve their weight loss, healthy eating and exercise goals.

data.name: L3324
data.value: Patients should be referred who have been diagnosed with prediabetes (A1C 6.0 to 6.4 % and/or fasting blood sugar 6.1 to 6.9 mmol/L) OR patients with diabetes risk factors (the program will confirm eligibility with CANRISK). All patients diagnosed with prediabetes must still go through the appropriate steps to confirm their eligibility including getting their blood tests done again.

data.name: L3326
data.value: It is being offered to particpants in major cities in Southern Ontario, and Ottawa and Winnipeg and will be expanding to more locations across the country soon.

Please ask your patient to share the baseline and follow-up reports that are provided as part of the program. Your ongoing support and encouragement are critical to your patient’s long-term success in making and sustaining important lifestyle changes.

data.value: Stand with your feet shoulder width apart (25 to 30 centimetres or 10 to 12 inches) and back straight.

data.name: L3416
data.value: Locate the top of the hip bone. This is the part of the hip bone at the side of the waist not at the front of the body. Use the area between the thumb and index finger to feel for the hip bone at the side of the waist.

data.name: L3417
data.value:
Align the bottom edge of the measuring tape with the top of the hip bone. Wrap the tape measure all the way around the waist.
Ensure that the tape measure is parallel to the floor and not twisted.

data.name: L3418

data.value:
Thank you for your time and interest in the Canadian Diabetes Prevention Program. Based on your responses, you are at a higher risk of developing type 2 diabetes in the future, and you qualify for this free program.

Many years before people develop type 2 diabetes, most of them develop prediabetes, which you may already have based on your score. This individualized coaching program can empower you to lead a healthier lifestyle and reduce your risk of developing type 2 diabetes.

Get Started Today
Step 1: Click the button below to create your profile
Step 2: A specialist will call you in the next two business days

Do not delay. Prediabetes and type 2 diabetes are serious chronic diseases.

data.value: Your Diabetes Risk Test score is {0}. A score of 5 or higher is associated with an increased risk for having type 2 diabetes.

data.name: L3591
data.value: Your Diabetes Risk Test score is calculated from your responses to questions in the health assessment but does not take into consideration your blood test results. It is based on the American Diabetes Association’s type 2 diabetes risk test. Higher scores are associated with a higher risk for having type 2 diabetes or prediabetes (a condition that precedes type 2 diabetes in which blood glucose levels are higher than normal). A score of 5 or higher is associated with an especially increased risk for having prediabetes or type 2 diabetes.
